questions.text: The antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is:
questions.solution:
Antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is emtricitabine.

It is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor similar to lamivudine. It has activity against HIV-1, HIV-2, and HBV.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of low-grade fever and progressive chest pain. Chest X-ray revealed the following. Considering the symptoms and imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow, called the money bag appearance. Considering the above symptoms and the chest X-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis is pericardial effusion. 

The investigation of choice is echocardiography. However, the following x-ray findings are also characteristic for pericardial effusion:

  • AP view - money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart
  • Lateral view - Oreo cookie sign (fluid is seen between two layers of fat)

In the following image, pericardial fluid (yellow asterisk) outlined by paracardial fat (blue arrows) and epicardial fat (orange arrows) is called the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium bovis?

choices.text: Nitrate test is positive in both Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium bovis.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis shows dysgonic growth and Mycobacterium bovis has eugonic growth.
0.5% glycerol helps growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis , but not Mycobacterium bovis.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis is resistant to pyrazinamidase 4 days but  Mycobacterium bovis is not resistant.

questions.solution:
O.5% glycerol helps in growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, but not Mycobacterium bovis.

Differences:

Test M. tuberculosis M. bovis

Growth in TCH + -

Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (MTC or MTBC) is a genetically related group of Mycobacterium species that can cause tuberculosis in humans or other living organisms.

M. tuberculosis complex includes the following:

  1. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  2. Mycobacterium africanum
  3. Mycobacterium orygis
  4. Mycobacterium bovis and the Bacillus Calmette–Guérin strain
  5. Mycobacterium microti

  10. Mycobacterium mungi

questions.text: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign.

In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions. This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign. 

Sonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Single placental mass
  • Presence of intervening membrane - T sign
  • Thin intervening membrane <2mm

The best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34 - 37weeks + 6 days.

Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda sign

Image 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between them

Image 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs

questions.text: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not be seen?
questions.solution:
An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora.

A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organ­isms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. 

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of dribbling of urine from the vagina during micturition. She has a history of obstructed labor. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done, and the lowest swab gets stained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a urethrovaginal fistula.

Urethrovaginal fistulas have the following clinical features:

  • Continent and dry at rest
  • Urinary dribbling during micturition
  • Fistulous opening is seen on per speculum examination

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text:
Which of the following should not be incinerated?
  1. Sharps and waste with heavy metals
  2. Reactive chemical waste
  3. Specimens of microorganisms
  4. Pressurized gas containers
  5. Live or attenuated vaccines
questions.solution:
Specimens of microorganisms and live or attenuated vaccines can be incinerated.

Wastes that should not be incinerated are:

  • Sharps
  • Pressurized gas containers
  • Reactive chemical waste
  • Waste with heavy metals like mercury and cadmium
  • PVC
  • Photographic or radiographic waste

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of _______
questions.solution:
Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Schiller's test?

choices.text: Lugol's iodine is used to paint the cervix
The epithelium is stained mahogany brown
It detects the presence of glycogen in the epithelium

questions.solution:
The abnormal cells remain unstained on performing Schiller's test.

Schiller's test, also known as VILI (visual inspection with Lugol's iodine), involves painting the cervix with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the cervix and vagina, such as in cases of carcinoma cervix. 

The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen, therefore stains mahogany brown on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.

questions.text: All of the following will be your differential diagnosis in a patient with anterior mediastinal mass except:
questions.solution:
Neurogenic tumors are found in the posterior mediastinum and not in the anterior mediastinum.

They are the most common primary tumors of the posterior mediastinum. Schwannomas and Neurilemomas are the most common neurogenic tumors.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic patient presented to the ED with complaints of chest pain on exertion. Laboratory tests showed dyslipidemia and features of metabolic syndrome. Which of the following drugs was recently approved for this condition?
questions.solution:
Saroglitazar is a dual PPAR alpha/gamma agonist and is approved for diabetic dyslipidemia only in India.

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are a superfamily of nuclear receptors involved in the regulation of energy homeostasis and metabolic function. It has three subtypes:

  • PPARα - reduces triglyceride level 
  • PPARγ - causes insulin sensitization 
  • PPARδ - enhances fatty acids metabolism

Of the three PPAR isoforms, synthetic pharmaceutical ligands that activate PPARalpha (the antidyslipidemic fibrates) and PPARgamma (the antidiabetic thiazolidinediones) have been studied extensively. Recently developed dual PPARalpha/gamma agonists combine the therapeutic effects of these drugs to be used in type 2 diabetes with dyslipidemia. 

Options A and C - Aleglitazar and muraglitazar are also dual PPAR alpha/gamma agonists but their development was halted due to increased risk of cardiovascular mortality.

Option D - Rosiglitazone is a PPAR gamma agonist indicated in type 2 diabetes mellitus. It has been withdrawn from many countries including India due to increased cardiovascular mortality.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-month-old infant to the OPD with complaints of him crying while urinating. On palpation, a left-sided flank mass is felt. A USG KUB revealed dilation of the pelvicalyceal system with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the investigation of choice to confirm his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Delayed clearance of contrast or the radiotracer implies obstruction.

Renal isotope scans have replaced intravenous pyelogram as the diagnostic modality of choice in UPJ obstruction.

  • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function.
  • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function. Hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR.

In obstructive uropathy, 99mTc-DTPA is the preferred isotope as glomerular function declines earlier and more rapidly than tubular function.

Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 

Tc-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring. 

Note: In children, crying before and after micturition is usually considered normal. While crying during micturition is usually suggestive of pathology.

questions.text: A college student is fed up with wearing spectacles for her myopia. During her annual eye checkup, she asks the ophthalmologist for eye surgery to get rid of the glasses. Which of the following is not a surgical option to correct her refractive error?
questions.solution:
Conductive keratoplasty is a cornea-based surgical procedure used in the correction of hypermetropia.

Surgical procedures are undertaken after the stabilization of myopia which usually occurs after 18 years of age.

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Refractive lens exchange

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Phakic intraocular lens
Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Clear lens extraction
Orthokeratology  
Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: A panicked primigravida, at 38 weeks of gestation, rushes to the ER at 3 am as she had not appreciated any fetal movements since 10 pm. She is taken up for an emergency c-section in view of fetal distress. Following delivery, the infant was cyanotic and apneic. What is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Room air is the preferred initial gas for neonatal resuscitation in term infants.

Resuscitation with room air in term infants is as effective as using 100% oxygen. By using room air, we may reduce the risk of hyperoxia which is associated with decreased cerebral blood flow and generation of oxygen free radicals.

If the neonate does not achieve normal oxygen saturation levels within 90 seconds, increased concentrations of oxygen are administered until normal saturation levels are achieved.

If pulmonary hypertension is suspected (meconium aspiration, diaphragmatic hernia), one may consider 100% oxygen as the initial gas for resuscitation. Resuscitation of most preterm infants can be initiated with a slightly higher fraction of inspired oxygen (21–30%).

questions.text: Which of the following echinocandins does not undergo hepatic metabolism?
questions.solution:
Anidulafungin is cleared by slow chemical degradation from the body. No hepatic metabolism or renal excretion of active drug occurs. 

Clinical correlate: No dose adjustment is required in hepatic or renal impairment for anidulafungin. Drug interactions are also not clinically significant with with drugs likely to be coadministered with anidulafungin.  

Options A and B: Caspofungin and micafungin undergoes hepatic metabolism before excretion.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with loss of function mutation in RET proto-oncogene?
questions.solution:
Loss of function mutation in RET proto-oncogene is associated with Hirschsprung's disease.

Hirschsprung's disease is caused by mutations in other genes encoding proteins involved in enteric neurodevelopment. These include:

  • RET ligand glial-derived neurotrophic factor
  • Endothelin
  • Endothelin receptor

Note: Medullary thyroid carcinoma and multiple endocrine neoplasias, types 2A and 2B are usually due to gain of function mutations in RET proto-oncogene.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is NADPH. The most important source of NADPH is the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway.

The HMP shunt pathway, or pentose phosphate pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It generates NADPH and synthesizes ribose. NADP+ is hydrogenated to NADPH by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. Since the HMP shunt pathway and de novo fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. Thus, this forms the major source for NADPH for fatty acid synthesis. 

Other minor sources of NADPH are extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase and NADP malate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme). 

Related Pearl: Reducing Equivalents and Their Uses

Uses

NADPH

Lipid synthesis

Cholesterol synthesis

NADH

Metabolizes alcohol

Oxidative phosphorylation

questions.text: A hospital inpatient, in an intensive care unit, for the past two days was noticed to be agitated and showing hallucinatory behavior. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the clinical scenario is best explained by encephalopathy. Acute onset of agitation and hallucinations can occur in delirium caused by encephalopathy. 

Other options:

Absence of a history of seizure  in the question rules out postictal confusion.

White coat syndrome is a condition where a patient’s blood pressure is higher when taken in a medical setting than it is in other settings, such as at home probably because of associated anxiety and stress at a clinical setting

Ganser syndrome also known as “Prison psychosis” or “Syndrome of approximate answers” is a type of conversion/dissociative disorder. It is characterized by giving of approximate answers (Vorbeireden) to questions. The answers often just miss the mark but bear an obvious relation to the question, indicating that it has been understood.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old patient underwent a CABG procedure. He started shivering within 15 minutes of shifting him to the post-operative ward. His temperature was 35.5-degrees Celcius. Which of the following agents can be used to treat this patient?
  1. Meperidine
  2. Dexmedetomidine
  3. Remifentanil
  4. Ondansetron
  5. Tramadol
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of postoperative hypothermia and shivering in this patient. Remifentanil is known to cause postoperative shivering when given in high doses and has no role in the treatment of this patient.

Postoperative hypothermia is defined as a core temperature < 36°C. Postoperative shivering is usually, but not always, associated with hypothermia. The primary cause of postoperative shivering is perioperative hypothermia. The most efficient way to reduce post-anaesthetic shivering is to prevent hypothermia by avoiding cold epidural and intravenous fluids.

Treatment-

  • Meperidine is the most effective treatment for post-anesthetic hypothermia and shivering.
  • Opioids(Tramadol), ondansetron, clonidine, physostigmine and ketamine have been shown to be effective in abolishing shivering.
  • Intraoperative infusion of dexmedetomidine has been shown to be an effective prophylactic.

questions.text: A married woman with complaints of delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized behavior for the past 6 months, was recently diagnosed with schizophrenia. She has been on antidepressants for 2 years. Which of the following would confer her a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
The absence of a precipitating event (stressor) is a poor prognostic factor for schizophrenia.

Good Prognostic factors  Poor prognostic factors
Acute onset Insidious onset
Late-onset Early-onset
Presence of a stressor Absence of a stressor
Short duration < 6 months Duration >2 years
Presence of depression No depression
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Family history of mood disorder Family history of schizophrenia
Married, female sex Single, male sex
Catatonic schizophrenia Hebephrenic schizophrenia
Type 1 schizophrenia Type 2 schizophrenia

T.J.Crow classified schizophrenia into two separate types  :

Type 1 Type 2
Positive symptoms present  Negative symptoms present
More responsive to treatment Less responsive to treatment
No demonstrable neuropathology Demonstrable neuropathology (CT/MRI)
Good prognosis Poor prognosis

questions.text: Tinea unguium is a dermatophyte infection of ______.
questions.solution:
Tinea unguium is a dermatophytic infection of the nail plate. Onychomycosis is a broad term for all fungal nail infections. 

Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases.

It presents with yellowish discoloration, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

Six distinct patterns of tinea unguium have been described.

  1. Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) (most common)
  2. Superficial onychomycosis (SO)
  3. Proximal subungual onychomycosis
  4. Endonyx onychomycosis
  5. Totally dystrophic onychomycosis
  6. Mixed onychomycosis

Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curettings that include dystrophic subungual debris.

questions.text: In which of the following sites does HMP shunt occur?
questions.solution: HMP shunt takes place in the cytosol as enzymes needed for the HMP shunt (pentose phosphate) pathway are located in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: The following antigen is produced by all of the following pathogens except__________.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Superantigen. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. This means they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocaspid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  • Fungal
    • Malassezia furfur.

questions.text: The arterial supply of the pancreas is mainly by branches of__________.

choices.text: Right gastric, splenic and right renal  arteries
Common hepatic, gastroduodenal, and splenic artery
Coeliac trunk and superior mesenteric artery

questions.solution:
The arterial supply of the pancreas is mainly by branches of the coeliac trunk and the superior mesenteric artery. 

Arterial supply of the pancreas:

  • Head and uncinate process
    • Anterior and posterior superior pancreatoduodenal arteries [branches of the gastroduodenal artery, which is a branch of the celiac trunk]
    • Anterior and posterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries [branches of the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery, which is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery]
  • Body and tail [branches of the splenic artery, which is a branch of the celiac trunk]
    • Dorsal pancreatic artery
    • Great pancreatic artery
    • Artery to the tail of the pancreas

Options A and C: While all the given branches of the coeliac trunk do supply the pancreas, these options do not include branches from the superior mesenteric artery. So, option D is more complete and thus it is the better option.

Option B: Right gastric and right renal arteries do not supply the pancreas.

The image given below shows the blood supply of the pancreas.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early sign of death?
questions.solution:
Rigor mortis is an early sign of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

questions.text: Alpha helix and beta pleated sheet are examples of the ______ structure of a protein.
questions.solution:
Alpha helix and beta-pleated sheets are examples of the secondary structure of a protein.

The secondary structure of a protein refers to the folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of a polypeptide chain. Examples include alpha helix, beta sheets, turns and bends. 

Related Pearl: Structure of proteins

questions.text: Which of the following occurs after hyperventilation with 6% CO2 in inspired air?
questions.solution:
Hyperventilation with 6% CO2 is followed by continued hyperventilation till alveolar Pco2 drops towards normal.

Ventilatory responses to CO2

There is a linear relationship between increase in % of CO2 in inspired air and respiratory minute volume.

  • The upper limit for this linearity is 6% of alveolar PCO2.
  • When the CO2 content of the inspired gas is >7%, the alveolar and the arterial PCO2 begin to rise abruptly in spite of hyperventilation leading to hypercapnia.
    • Hypercapnia depresses the central nervous system, including respiratory centers leading to CO2 narcosis (a headache, confusion and eventually coma).

Mechanism:

Increased CO2 in inspired air ⇒ Increased Alveolar PCO2 ⇒ Increased arterial PCO2 ⇒ Stimulation of central chemoreceptors ⇒   Stimulation of ventilation ⇒ Alveolar PCO2 drops toward normal

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of weakness, restlessness, and chest pain. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg, his heart sounds are muffled, and his neck veins are distended. What is the typical JVP finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention (Beck’s triad) are the three principal features of cardiac tamponade. The typical JVP finding here is absent y-descent.

JVP shows a prominent x (early systolic) descent and an absent y (early diastolic) descent because of the ventricle's limited or absent early diastolic filling. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp.

There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade.

Note: Alternation of QRS complexes, usually in a 2:1 ratio, on ECG is called electrical alternans. It is caused by the movement of the heart in the pericardial space. Electrical alternans is also seen in patients with myocardial ischemia, acute pulmonary embolism, and tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted with third-degree burns presents with light-headedness and oliguria on the third day of admission. On examination, the peripheries are warm and capillary refill is brisk. His pulse rate is 138/min. In which of the following types of shock do you see this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is seen in septic shock.

In distributive (septic) shock, the peripheries are warm and capillary refill will be brisk, despite the profound shock.

In early stages (compensated stage) of septic shock, the patient has clammy, warm peripheries. The latter is a distinct feature from other types of shock where peripheral vasoconstriction leads to cold peripheries. The patient will have decreased vascular resistance, inadequate afterload, abnormally high cardiac output, and tachycardia.

In the later stages (uncompensated phase) of septic shock, there is reduced venous return, preload, and reduced cardiac output with low blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is most prone to non-union?
questions.solution:
Among the given fractures, proximal scaphoid fractures are most prone to non-union. 

Since the nutrient artery enters the scaphoid near its distal end, proximal fractures are associated with avascular necrosis and non-union. The more proximal the fracture in the scaphoid, the higher the chances of avascular necrosis and non-union.

Certain bones have a relatively limited or watershed blood supply that can potentially get interrupted by fracture. These include:

  • Head of the femur: after fracture of the neck or posterior dislocation of the hip.
  • Proximal scaphoid: due to fracture through the waist of the scaphoid.
  • Lunate: following a dislocation.
  • Body of talus: after fracture of its neck.

Fractures in these sites have a higher risk for non-union or development of osteonecrosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Inter-trochanteric fractures involve either the greater or lesser trochanters or both, more common in the elderly following a history of a fall. Malunion is the most frequent complication. The vast metaphyseal region has an abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and fewer chances of avascular necrosis. 

Option C: Distal radius fractures occur by fall on an outstretched hand and they include Colles' fracture (most common), Smith's fracture, Barton's fracture, and Chauffer's fracture. The complications include joint stiffness, malunion (more common), carpal tunnel syndrome, subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint, Sudeck's dystrophy, and rupture of the extensor pollicis longus tendon. Avascular necrosis or non-union is rare.

Option D: Olecranon fracture results from a direct injury as in a fall onto the point of the elbow. Complications include non-union, elbow stiffness, and osteoarthritis.

questions.text: While doing the Raygat's test, an unrespired lung may float due to:
questions.solution:
In Raygat's test, an unrespired lung (stillbirth) may float due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction.

It is also known as the floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ hydrostatic test. It is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not:

  • If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth
  • If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, signifies stillborn

A respired lung (live birth) may sink in water in the following conditions:

  • Lung edema
  • Lung collapse
  • Pneumonia (consolidation)
  • Congenital syphilis

Other tests to determine if respiration has taken place or not are: 

  • Fodere’s test: Weight of lungs before respiration - 30-40g, after respiration - 60-66g
  • Ploucquet’s test: Weight of lungs before respiration - 1/70 of body weight, after respiration - 1/35 of body weight 
  • Wredin’s test: Assesses the changes in the middle ear. The gelatinous substance in the middle ear is replaced by air if respiration has taken place.

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: Urea cycle and Krebs cycle are linked at____.
questions.solution:
The urea cycle and Kreb's cycle are linked at fumarate.

In the urea cycle, cleavage of argininosuccinate to arginine releases the aspartate skeleton as fumarate. Fumarate in Kreb's cycle, by the addition of water, converts to L-malate.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a CXC chemokine?
questions.solution:
IL­-8 is a typical example of a CXC chemokine.

Chemokines are a family of small (8 to 10 kD) proteins. They act primarily as chemoattractants for specific types of leukocytes.

They are classified into 4 groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins. This is given in the image and the table below.

Type of chemokine Structure Action and example
C-X-C 1 amino acid residue separating the first 2 of the 4 conserved cysteine residues

Involved in neutrophil activation and chemotaxis

Example- IL-8
C-C The first 2 conserved cysteine residues remain adjacent

Attract monocytes, eosinophils, basophils, lymphocytes

Examples:

  • Monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP­1)
  • Eotaxin
  • Macrophage inflammatory protein­ 1α (MIP­1α)
  • Regulated and normal T­-cell expressed and secreted (RANTES)
C chemokines Lack the 1st and 3rd of the 4 conserved cysteines

Specific for lymphocytes

Example - lymphotactin
CX3C Contain 3 amino acids between the 2 cysteines

The only known member of this class is called fractalkine.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man began to suspect that his wife was cheating on him. He started to follow her and often woke her up in the middle of the night to make accusations, even though she was not having an affair. He even tried to physically harm her because of his suspicions. What is his most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Othello syndrome/morbid jealousy/delusion of infidelity is when the person believes that his/her partner is unfaithful and is cheating on him/her.

This can present as a primary delusional disorder, or it can be a symptom of other disorders like schizophrenia, alcohol-related psychosis, mood disorders, etc.

The Tragedy of Othello, the Moor of Venice, a Shakespearean play, revolves around two characters, Othello and Iago. Othello is a Moorish general who has just married Desdemona, a beautiful and wealthy Venetian. Iago, Othello's jealous and bitter ensign, plans to exploit his master to his own advantage, and maliciously goads Othello until he kills his beloved wife in a fit of blind rage.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: On examining a patient with an injury around the elbow, you notice that the three-point bony relationship is maintained. This finding can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained in case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. This is because the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with schizoaffective disorder and was prescribed a drug. Soon after initiation of therapy, she developed galactorrhea and dysmenorrhea, and her prolactin level was 171.6ng/mL. Which drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Risperidone causes the maximum rise in prolactin levels and has the highest potential to cause hyperprolactinemia among the atypical antipsychotics.

Risperidone is an antagonist of 5-HT2A and D2 receptors. The combined use of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) can also result in a significant elevation of prolactin with galactorrhea and breast enlargement.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy?

choices.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.solution:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland. 

The disadvantage of a high tracheostomy is subglottic stenosis at the level of the cricoid and perichondritis of the cricoid. However, in laryngeal carcinoma this would be a temporary measure as the definitive management is total laryngectomy.

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.solution:

questions.text: Non-convulsive status epilepticus is associated with the use of__________.
questions.solution:
Encephalopathy and non-convulsive status epilepticus have been reported with the use of cefepime. 

The mechanism of neurotoxicity in cephalosporin therapy involves inhibiting GABA-A release, increasing glutamate levels, and inducing the release of endotoxins and TNF-alpha, which is involved in septic encephalopathy.

questions.text: Which serological marker can be used to diagnose acute hepatitis B in the window period?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of acute hepatitis B in the window period or serological gap can be made by the detection of the anti-HBc antibody.

The window period is the period between the disappearance of HBsAg to anti-HBs seroconversion. During this window period, anti-HBc is the only detectable antibody.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male on multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg for the last 7 days. The patient gives a history of similar episodes in the past which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, Analgesics, and Hypnotics.

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome).

questions.text:
Vaccines included under Intensified mission Indradhanush scheme are:
a. JE
b. Rota virus
c. Typhoid
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis and rota virus vaccines are included under Intensified mission Indradhanush scheme.

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunisation are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month). The diseases are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Russel-Silver Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Russel silver syndrome is a growth disorder characterized by slow growth before and after birth. Hence, it presents as Low birth weight, not macrosomia.

Features:

Normal Head growth is present but affected children are thin and have a poor appetite.

Low birth weight and failure to thrive are often associated.  

Parent-specific differences in gene expression are caused due to genomic imprinting.

Hence Uniparental disomy can cause it.

Genes in chromosome 7 and 11 are involved in this.

questions.text: The examination findings of a pregnant woman are suggestive of her having conjoined twins. Which is the most common type of such twins?
questions.solution:
Thoracopagus is the most common type of conjoined twins.

Division of the inner cell mass after the 12th day of fertilization results in the development of conjoined or Siamese twins. Based on the parts of the body joined, they are of the following types:

  • Ventral
    • Rostral
      • Omphalopagus (abdomen)
      • Thoracopagus (upper chest)
      • Cephalopagus (head)
    • Caudal
      • Ischiopagus (conjoined spines at 180 angle)
    • Lateral
      • Paraphagus (side by side fusion with a shared pelvis)
  • Dorsal
    • Craniopagus (skull)
    • Rachipagus (vertebral arches)
    • Pyopagus (pelvis)

Sharing of organs is common among conjoined twins. MRI imaging is done later in pregnancy for the evaluation of organ sharing between conjoined twins who are being planned for surgical separation.

questions.text: What is the type of strangulation shown in this image called?
questions.solution:
The image shows the tightening of a noose around the neck by twisting a rod within the ligature. This is called garrotting. 

This is a mode of ligature strangulation that may be seen in homicide.

This was a form of judicial execution once employed in Spain. The rod-like object used to tighten the ligature is called a Spanish windlass - this may be a ruler, stick, or screwdriver. The method was also used by Thagi’s in the past in India, to kill the travelers and rob their belongings in lonely places.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Atypical types of RP are as follows:

  • Sectoral RP
  • Pericentric/Inverse RP
  • RP sine pigmento
  • RP punctata albescens

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: 500 mg of mannitol was injected out of which 10% is excreted. After equilibrium, plasma concentration is 3.2 mg/100 ml. Calculate ECF Volume (L).
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution can be calculated using the formula:

  • V = volume of compartment
  • Amount injected = 500 mg
  • Amount of indicator excreted = 10% of 500 mg = 50mg
  • Plasma concentration of the indicator = 3.2 mg/100mL

Calculation:

2nd method : 

Mannitol is a substance which leaves blood vessel but can't enter the cell. Therefore, after attaining equilibrium, conc. of mannitol is same in plasma and interstitial fluid 

Therefore, by applying dye-dilution technique, mannitol can be used to measure the volume of ECF (x)

Since, 10% is excreted and 10% of 500mg is 50 mg, the amount of mannitol diluted in ECF is 450 mg (500 - 50) i.e, 450 mg is present in x 

From the given values, 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, which can be re-written as

      3.2/100 = 450/x

Therefore x = 450 * 100 / 3.2 mL

                    = 14,062.5 mL

                    = 14 L

Clinical :

IV Mannitol is used to treat cerebral oedema (since, it doesn't cross cell membrane, it extracts fluid from brain cells), whereas it is contra-indicated in pulmonary edema (here the fluid collection is in the interstitial space)

questions.text: Neprilysin inhibitor among the following is
questions.solution:
Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor that is indicated in combination with valsartan in chronic heart failure.

Fosinopril, benazepril and quinapril are angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (Options A,B and D).

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will you perform the Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for extrahepatic biliary atresia. In the Kasai procedure, the occluded extrahepatic bile ducts are excised and a jejunal Roux loop is anastomosed to the hepatic hilum.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct between porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation.

Associated anomalies include cardiac lesions, polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava, and a preduodenal portal vein.

HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for EHBA. Intraoperative cholangiogram is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management of extrahepatic biliary atresia
Type I

Atresia restricted to the common bile duct

Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II

Atresia of the common hepatic duct

 Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy)
Type III

Atresia of the right and left hepatic duct

Infants with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after Kasai's procedure, require liver transplantation within the first year of life. It is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children.

Kasai procedure:

questions.text:
Arrange the following sites of ectopic pregnancy from the most common to the least common.
  1. Interstitium
  2. Isthmus
  3. Ampulla
  4. Fimbriae
questions.solution:
The order of the most common site to the least common site in the fallopian tube for ectopic pregnancy is ampulla>isthmus>fimbriae>interstitium.

An ectopic pregnancy is any pregnancy implanted outside of the endometrial cavity.

Extrauterine sites: The most common site of ectopic pregnancy is the extrauterine fallopian tube. 

  • Tubal - 97% (most common)
    • Ampulla - 55%
    • Isthmus
    • Infundibulum
    • Interstitium
  • Ovarian
  • Abdominal

Intrauterine ectopic sites:

  • Cervical
  • Caesarean scar 
  • Rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus
  • Heterotopic pregnancy

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: Under the National Programme for Control of Blindness & Visual Impairment, NGO eye hospitals are considered as:
questions.solution:
NGO eye hospitals are considered secondary level centres under the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI).

Levels of eye care centres according to NPCBVI:

  • Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centres, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, and link workers.
  • Secondary level: District hospitals and NGO eye hospitals.
  • Tertiary level: Regional institutes of ophthalmology and medical colleges.

The goal of NPCBVI is to reduce the prevalence of blindness to 0.25% by 2025.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency in an unresponsive state. There is an alleged history of consumption of multiple prescription tablets in an attempt to commit suicide. After the drug was conclusively identified, the doctor recommends dialysis for definitive management. The drug most likely is:
questions.solution:
The drug most likely is lithium as it is the only one amongst the given drugs that can be removed by dialysis. It is the treatment of choice in case of severe lithium toxicity (>4mEq/L). 

The distribution of lithium is mainly restricted to the vascular compartment and it is not bound to any plasma proteins. Dialysis is effective in removing the drugs if they are sufficiently present in the free form in the plasma. Therefore, lithium can be removed by dialysis during an overdose.

Drugs not suitable for dialysis are those with:

  • High volume of distribution - digoxin, verapamil, and organophosphates 
  • High level of plasma protein binding - diazepam 

Related Pearl: Dialyzable and non-dialyzable drugs

Common dialyzable drugs: 

  • Barbiturates
  • Lithium
  • Salicylates
  • Theophylline/Caffeine (both are methylxanthines)
  • Methanol
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Sodium valproate
  • Isoniazid
  • Carbamazepine

Common Non-Dialyzable Drugs (AVOID Dialysis):

  • A- Amphetamines
  • V- Verapamil
  • O- Opiates, Organophosphorous
  • I- Imipramine
  • D- Digoxin
  • Dialysis- Diazepam

questions.text: Selexipag is indicated in the management of pulmonary arterial hypertension. The mechanism of action of selexipag is:
questions.solution:
Selexipag is a selective prostacyclin receptor agonist. 

It is an orally active, selective IPR agonist and is chemically distinct from other PGI2 analogues.

questions.text: Identify the artery of epistaxis in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked 3 is the sphenopalatine artery which is also known as the artery of epistaxis.

It is called the artery of epistaxis because the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is derived from it. It is also the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

1 - Anterior ethmoidal artery

2 - Posterior ethmoidal artery

4 - Greater palatine artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with bleeding per rectum and weight loss. He underwent an endorectal ultrasound whose findings are given below. A diagnosis of rectal carcinoma was made and the patient was posted for total mesorectal excision. Which of the following is contained in the excised structure?
questions.solution:
The mesorectum is excised in total mesorectal excision. It contains the superior rectal vein.

The rectum has no mesentery attached to it. However, it is surrounded by fat which is enclosed within a fascial envelope known as the mesorectum, which contains:

  • Superior rectal artery and its branches
  • Superior rectal vein and  its tributaries
  • Lymphatic vessels and nodes

Anterolaterally, branches of the inferior hypogastric plexus and middle rectal vessels enter the mesorectum covered in a layer of fascia which is known as the lateral rectal ligament.

Total mesrectal excision (TME) is a standard procedure done for rectal cancer. It includes resection of tumor along with the surrounding fatty tissues, blood vessels and lympatics present in the mesorectum.

questions.text: Which of the following nuclei do not belong to the general visceral efferent column?
questions.solution:
Nucleus ambiguus does not belong to the general visceral efferent (GVE) column.

The general visceral efferent columns contain nuclei of parasympathetic cranial nerves:

  • III - Edinger-Westphal nucleus
  • VII - Superior salivatory nucleus
  • IX - Inferior salivatory nucleus
  • X - Dorsal motor nucleus of vagus.

Nucleus ambiguus belongs to the special visceral efferent (SVE) column.

The special visceral efferent column contains neurons innervating muscles developed from the pharyngeal arches:

  • Motor nucleus of V nerve- muscles of mastication
  • Motor nucleus of VII nerve- muscles of facial expression
  • Nucleus ambiguus (IX, X, XI)- stylopharyngeus, pharyngeal, external laryngeal, oesophageal striated muscles, muscles of the soft palate, sternocleidomastoid, and trapezius.

Related Pearl: Arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem

Functional Component Cranial nerves 

General Somatic Efferent (SE/GSE)

 3,4,6,12

Special Visceral Efferent (SVE/BrE)

5,7,9,10,11

General Visceral Efferent  (GVE)

 3,7,9,10

General Visceral Afferent (GVA)

 7,9,10

Special Visceral Afferent (BrA/SVA)

General Somatic Afferent (SA/GSA)

 5,7,9,10

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA)

 2,8

GVE represents the parasympathetic supply; so all cranial nerves having parasympathetic fibers, have the GVE component.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who presented with weight loss and abdominal discomfort is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C .  All the following factors can determine the progression of liver disease in this patient except:
questions.solution:
While HCV RNA is considered the gold standard for establishing a diagnosis of hepatitis C, it has no role in determining the progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C.

The likelihood of progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C is increased by:

  • Longer duration of infection - most important determinant
  • Older age
  • Obesity - patients with a high body mass index are at an increased risk of developing fibrosis
  • Diabetes mellitus and insulin resistance
  • Concomitant liver disorder (eg., alcoholic liver disease, chronic hepatitis B, hemochromatosis)
  • Concomitant HIV infection.

The best prognostic indicator in chronic hepatitis C is the rate of fibrosis and baseline inflammation seen in liver histology.

questions.text: What is the best indicator of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
The perinatal mortality rate is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: What is the single most important galactopoetic hormone in post-natal women?
questions.solution:
Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone in postnatal women.

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (ductal growth)

Progesterone (alveolar growth)
Lactogenesis Initiation of milk secretion Prolactin
Galactokinesis Ejection of milk Oxytocin
Galactopoiesis Maintainence of lactation Prolactin

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to:
questions.solution:
The given egg belongs to whipworm or Trichuris trichiura.

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

Whipworms live in the large intestine and whipworm eggs are passed in the feces of infected persons. The eggs develop in the soil in 3-4 weeks and become infective to man. When these embryonated eggs containing infective larvae contaminate food or water, they can cause infections in humans. 

 

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: For a membrane permeable substance, the intracellular concentration (IC) is 10 units and extracellular concentration (EC) is 5 units. If the intracellular concentration, surface area of the membrane and thickness of the membrane are doubled, and the EC remains the same, What will be the net effect on the diffusion?
questions.solution:
The net effect on the diffusion is, it becomes 3x.

The magnitude of the diffusion: 

where,
  • J = net rate of diffusion
  • D = diffusion coefficient
  • A = area of the membrane
  • Δx = thickness of the membrane or the distance the molecule must travel across for diffusion
  • Δc = concentration gradient

In the condition mentioned above, the surface area, the thickness of the membrane and intracellular concentration becomes doubled. This means,

  • A is doubled = 2A
  • Δx is doubled = 2Δx
  • IC is doubled. 10x2= 20 units; EC is 5 units.

So, Δc = 20 - 5 = 15. Δc was 5 with the original concentrations. Hence Δc has been tripled.

Now,

J=-D x 2A x 3Δc/2Δx = 3 x [DA Δc/Δx]

Therefore the diffusion of the substance increases by three-fold.

2nd method :

J = - DA (Δc / Δx )
After applying changes,Δc = intracellular conc. - extracellular conc.     = 10 - 5    = 5

Therefore, J1 = - DA (5 / Δx )

After appropriate doublings,      New intracellular conc. = 10 * 2 = 20      New extracellular conc. = 5 (since no change)     Δc = 20 - 5 = 15

Therefore, J2 = - D 2*A (15 / 2*Δx )                  

                   = - D A (15 / Δx )

Now,     J2  / J1 = [- DA (15 / Δx ) ] / [ = - DA (5 / Δx ) ]    

            J2  / J1  = 15 / 5 

                         = 3

Therefore the diffusion of the substance increases by three-fold.

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

The bacterial growth curve is obtained when a batch of bacteria is seeded in a liquid medium and incubated. It consists of 4 distinct phases:

  1. Lag phase (A) - The bacteria adapt to a new environment. They synthesize and accumulate enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication. Thus, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases. Maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
  2. Log or exponential phase (B) - The bacteria start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. The growth rate is constant. 
  3. Stationary phase (C) - There is depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Thus, cell division reduces and a state of equilibrium is attained, where the number of new cells formed equals the number that die. Growth rate is zero. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  4. Death phase or the phase of decline (D) - Growth rate is negative. The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with involuntary, sudden jerking movements of both upper limbs. They occur most frequently in the morning after awakening and are provoked by a lack of sleep. EEG demonstrates bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow- wave discharges. Which of the following features is not seen in this type of seizure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myoclonic seizures. Post-ictal paralysis is not seen in these seizures.

Myoclonic seizures are characterized by preserved consciousness (rarely very short loss of consciousness), preserved postural control, Lack of postictal confusion.

Myoclonic seizures usually coexist with other forms of generalized seizures but are the predominant feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME). The EEG shows bilaterally synchronous spike-and-slow wave discharges. 

JME or Janz's syndrome is an epilepsy syndrome that has familial inheritance and begins in adolescence. It most commonly occurs in the morning and is provoked by sleep deprivation. JME is usually associated with GTCS and sometimes with absence seizures. EEG shows a typical 4-6 Hz polyspike and wave pattern. Treatment includes administration of sodium valproate.

questions.text: Which is the most anteriorly placed heart chamber?
questions.solution:
The right ventricle is the most anteriorly placed cardiac chamber.

The image below shows an MRI of the heart and its chambers.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis?

choices.text: Arthritis of 3 or more joint areas simultaneously

questions.solution:
Rheumatoid nodule is not a criteria for diagnosing rheumatoid arthritis.

Revised criteria for diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis include (recent):

  • Joint involvement
  • Antibodies/Serology
  • Acute-phase reactants
  • Duration of symptoms

questions.text: Concomitant measurement of aPTT and anti-factor Xa level distinguishes pseudo-resistance and true-resistance to heparin. What would be the most likely parameters in a patient with pseudo resistance?

choices.text: Therapeutic aPTT and subtherapeutic anti-factor Xa levels
Therapeutic anti-factor Xa and subtherapeutic aPTT levels
Both aPTT and anti-factor Xa are at subtherapeutic levels
Both aPTT and anti-factor Xa are at therapeutic levels

questions.solution:
Heparin resistance: Patients who fail to achieve a therapeutic aPTT with daily doses of heparin of 35,000 units or more. 

Concomitant measurement of aPTT and anti-factor Xa level distinguishes pseudo-resistance and true-resistance to heparin.

Pseudo-resistance: Therapeutic anti-factor Xa with subtherapeutic aPTT levels

True-resitance: Both aPTT and anti-factor Xa are at subtherapeutic levels 

Pseudo-resistance usually occurs if the aPTT is shorter than the control value prior to initiating heparin therapy because of high concentrations of factor VIII and fibrinogen. No further dose adjustments are required as anti-factor Xa levels are therapeutic. 

True resistance occurs due to increased levels of plasma proteins that compete with heparin or due to decreased antithrombin levels. The dose has to be increased to achieve therapeutic aPTT or anti-factor Xa levels. Severe antithrombin deficiency may require antithrombin concentrate.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the investigation of peripheral arterial disease?

choices.text: Duplex scanning is a non invasive technique
On doppler ultrasound a normal artery has a biphasic signal
DSA is now the standard technique used
Computed tomographic angiography is not used routinely to diagnose PAD

questions.solution:
A normal artery has a triphasic signal. The waveform becomes biphasic in mild-moderate stenosis and monophasic in severe stenosis.

Option A: Duplex scanning is a major non-invasive technique that uses B-mode ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel.

Option C: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is now the standard technique whereby the images obtained are digitized by computer and the extraneous background (bone, soft tissues, etc.) is removed to provide clearer images. 

Option D: Computed tomographic angiography (CTA), and conventional catheter-based angiography should not be used for routine diagnostic testing but are performed before potential revascularization. These tests define the anatomy that assists in planning for revascularization procedures.

questions.text: A patient with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia has mipomersen as part of his treatment regimen. By which of the following mechanisms does this drug act?
questions.solution:
Mipomersen is an antisense oligonucleotide that acts as an inhibitor of apo B-100 synthesis. 

Mipomersen binds to the mRNA of apo B-100 resulting in degradation of apo B-100 mRNA and eventually reduction of apo B-100 synthesis.

questions.text: Sensory supply of cornea is provided by
questions.solution:
Cornea is richly supplied by nerves  which originate  from small ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve, by long ciliary nerve( a branch of nasociliary nerve).

Sensory nerve supply of the eye.

Ophthalmic Nerve:

  • Lacrimal nerve
    • Lacrimal gland, Conjunctiva, Lateral eyelid
  • Frontal nerve
    • Conjunctiva, Eyelid, Part of forehead
  • Nasociliary nerve
    • Long ciliary nerve
      • Cornea
      • Ciliary body
      • Iris
    • Infra-trochlear nerve
      • Conjunctiva
      • Lacrimal sac
      • Caruncle
      • Medial part of eyelids

questions.text: How is multi-dose activated charcoal useful in cases of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Multidose activated charcoal (MDAC) is used for the enhanced elimination of a toxin.

In some instances, patients may benefit from the repeated administration of activated charcoal. MDAC facilitates the passage of substances from plasma into the intestinal lumen, enhancing elimination. Currently, MDAC is indicated for only the following poisons:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Theophylline
  • Phenobarbital
  • Salicylates
  • Dapsone
  • Quinine

The techniques used for general management of poisoning can be classified into

 Mechanism Techniques
Gastrointestinal decontamination

Orogastric lavage

Activated charcoal

Whole bowel irrigation
Enhanced elimination

Multi-dose activated charcoal

Urinary alkalinization

Extracorporeal removal (Hemodialysis, Hemoperfusion)
Administration of antidote

Mechanical antidotes

Chemical antidotes

Physiological antidotes

Pharmacological antidotes

questions.text: False statement about Hirschsprung’s disease is______

choices.text: It involves both the myenteric plexus and Meissner’s plexus
It is seen in infants only.
It can also involve the small intestine.

questions.solution:
Hirschsprung’s disease can also occur in older children.

Hirschsprung’s disease:

  • Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus.
  • Incidence: 1 in 5000 live births.
  • Boys are four times more frequently affected than girls.
  • Sites affected: Rectosigmoid (80%) > Splenic or transverse colon (17%) > Entire colon with variable extension to small bowel (8%).
  • The abnormal/aganglionic bowel is the constricted distal segment, whereas the normal bowel is the proximal dilated portion.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. Microscopic examination finding of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows hexagonal, translucent and white crystals suggestive of cystinuria. Histidine is not seen in the urine of this patient. 

Cystinuria is an autosomal-recessive disease due to a defect in renal PCT & intestinal amino acid transporter that is essential for reabsorptive transport of Cystine and the dibasic amino acids Ornithine, Lysine, and Arginine (COLA).

Diagnosis of cystinuria is by the cyanide–nitroprusside test. Initial treatment is with adequate hydration, alkalization of the urine with citrate supplementation or acetazolamide, and dietary modification to reduce salt and protein intake. If this fails then patients are usually started on chelation therapy with penicillamine.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is popularly used in clinical anaesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Ulnar nerve stimulation at wrist is popularly used to assess the adequacy of neuromuscular blockade.

Neuromuscular blockade is measured using a peripheral nerve stimulator.

Nerve Response
Ulnar nerve Contraction of adductor pollicis
Facial nerve Contraction of orbicularis oculi
Posterior tibial nerve Contraction of flexor hallucis brevis

questions.text: Among the following, which is the final structure to drain lymphatics from the stomach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the intestinal lymph trunk is the last structure to drain lymphatics from the stomach. 

The intestinal lymph trunk is a major lymphatic channel in the abdomen. It receives lymphatics from the pre-aortic group of lymph nodes such as coeliac nodes, superior mesenteric nodes, and inferior mesenteric nodes. The intestinal lymph trunk finally drains into the cisterna chyli.

The lymphatic drainage of the stomach can be divided into four zones as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 44-year old businessman came to the casualty with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis since early morning. He was diagnosed with depression 4 months back and has been on phenelzine. He gives the history of attending an office party the previous night where he consumed some red wine. On examination, his BP was 190/120. What is false about his present condition?

choices.text: The condition is less common with selegilline.
He is suffering from serotonin syndrome.
Tyramine is involved the pathogenesis of the condition.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction, not serotonin syndrome. Here, the patient on phenelzine (non-selective and irreversible MAO-inhibitor) developed the clinical features of cheese reaction on having a tyramine-rich food item (red wine, cheese, milk).

Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter the systemic circulation. It is taken up by adrenergic neurons and a hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of a powerful pressor effect of tyramine. 

The drug of choice to treat hypertensive crisis in cheese reaction is phentolamine. 

 

MAO-inhibitor with SSRI causes serotonin syndrome. Symptoms are fever, altered mental status, rigidity, hyperreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction.

Selegiline and rasagiline do not functionally inhibit MAO-A. They do not cause cheese reaction with doses used in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with pain over the lateral aspect of her right breast for the past 5 days. Examination finding is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein. Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast. It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Option A: Tietze’s syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska disease is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Option D: Stewart–Treves Syndrome is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: What waves can be seen on the EEG when a person is awake but their eyes are closed?
questions.solution: Alpha waves are seen when the person is relaxed with eyes closed.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man has a three-week history of speaking to himself and complains of hearing two people talking about him. On examination, he has reduced affect and impaired judgment. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of brief psychotic episode (DSM-5), as the symptoms are present for less than 30 days.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder in DSM-5 is based on the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month: 

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

According to ICD-11, this is classified as acute and transient psychotic disorder, and the duration of the episode does not last for more than 3 months.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a selective medium for Corynebacterium diptheriae?
questions.solution:
Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is not a selective medium as other organisms can also grow on this medium.

The selective media for Corynebacterium diphtheria are potassium tellurite agar, Tinsdale medium and McLeod's medium (tellurite blood agar). Tellurite inhibits the growth of other bacteria. C. diphtheria reduces the tellurite to metallic tellurium, giving its colonies a grey black colour. On 

On Loeffler's serum slope, colonies appear as small white opaque discs that may acquire a yellow ting. The advantages for growing C. diphtheriae on Loeffler's serum slope are rapid growth in 6-8 hrs and that its the best medium for metachromatic granules production. The disadvantage of using this medium is that on incubation beyond 6-8 hrs, it supports the growth of commensals as well.

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media
