questions.text: A 45-year-old woman suffering from Huntington's chorea is on haloperidol. Which of the following adverse drug effects is best attributed to the supersensitivity of dopamine receptors?

choices.text: Muscle rigidity, labile blood pressure, hyperreflexia, hyperthermia, tachycardia, tremors
Lip smacking, facial dyskinesia, protrusion and rolling of the tongue, involuntary movements of the extremities
Facial grimacing, involuntary upward eye movement, laryngeal spasm and arching of the trunk forward
Stooped posture, rigidity, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, and pill rolling tremors

questions.solution:
Lip-smacking, facial dyskinesia, protrusion and rolling of the tongue, and involuntary movements of the extremities are characteristic of tardive dyskinesia. This is caused by supersensitivity of dopamine receptors. 

It occurs as a consequence of chronic postsynaptic D2 receptor blockade by antipsychotics, which results in upregulation and supersensitivity of postsynaptic dopamine receptors.

Tardive dyskinesia is usually seen in patients treated with typical antipsychotics (first generation) for more than a year. This may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation. Treatment is with valbenazine, deutetrabenazine (VMAT2 inhibitors).

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text: Abdominal examination during a routine antenatal checkup gave a positive Stallworthy sign. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Stallworthy sign is observed in posterior placenta previa.

The slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis, which recovers promptly when the pressure is relieved, is called Stallworthy sign.

Note: This sign is not always significant as this could also occur in normal pregnancies due to fetal head compression.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. The child's parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

choices.text: The period of infectivity is 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common complication is pneumonia

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. The most common cause of death is pneumonia (Hecht's giant cell pneumonia).

Measles (rubeola) is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. The infection is spread via droplets, with a secondary attack rate ≥of 90%. The patients are infectious from 4 days before upto 5 days after the appearance of the rash. The rash appears on the 4th day of fever. It starts from the retro auricular region. Koplik spots are pathognomonic.

The most common cause of death is pneumonia. Measles can lead to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) as a late complication.

Measles can be prevented by administering live attenuated, Edmonston–Zagreb strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

4th disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the nerve involved in the palsy shown below is false?

choices.text: It divides into upper and lower divisions in the anterior part of the cavernous sinus.
Its divisions enter the orbit through the middle part of the superior orbital fissure.
It lies between the posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries in the interpeduncular fossa.
The nerve to inferior rectus carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion.

questions.solution:
The image shows oculomotor nerve palsy. The nerve to inferior oblique carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion, not the nerve to inferior rectus.

Course of the oculomotor nerve:

  • The nerve lies on the anterior surface of the midbrain in between the posterior cerebral artery and the superior cerebellar artery in the interpeduncular fossa.
  • It then passes to the middle cranial fossa along the lateral dural wall of the cavernous sinus and divides into superior and inferior in its anterior part.
  • It enters the superior orbital fissure through the common tendinous ring.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms does not lead to immune evasion by the tumor cells?

choices.text: Inhibition of PD-1 receptor on T-cells

questions.solution:
Inhibition of PD-1 receptor (programmed death -1 receptor) on T cells causes activation of immunity against the tumor cells, not evasion.

PD-1 receptors present on T cells inhibit T-cell activation. This allows tumors to evade the host immunity by the upregulation of the expression of factors like PD-L1 and PD-L2, which act on PD-1 receptors.

questions.text: The IVP imaging of a 30-year-old woman is given below. What is it diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram is characteristic for medullary sponge kidney. It shows ectatic distal collecting ducts containing microcalcifications, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. Dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla are also seen, which is known as paintbrush appearance. 

This is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by a lacunar stroke?
questions.solution:
Crural monoplegia with urinary incontinence is not caused by a lacunar stroke. It is caused by the occlusion of A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery. Crural monoplegia refers to a monoplegia of the lower limbs.

The types of lacunar syndromes are as follows:

  1. Pure motor hemiparesis - infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule
  2. Pure sensory stroke - infarct in the thalamus
  3. Ataxic hemiparesis - infarct in the pons or internal capsule
  4. Dysarthria and clumsy hand syndrome - infarction in the pons or internal capsule.

The ACA is divided into two segments:

  • The pre-communal (A1) circle of Willis, or stem, which connects the internal carotid artery to the anterior communicating artery
  • The post-communal (A2) segment distal to the anterior communicating artery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of patients with hydrargyrism?
questions.solution:
Hydrargyrism means mercury poisoning. Bowen's disease is associated with chronic low-level exposure to arsenic, not mercury.

Features of chronic mercury poisoning:

  • Tremors - most consistent manifestation. They are:
    • Danbury tremors - fine muscle fasciculations punctuated every few minutes by coarse shaking or jerky movements, intentional type. Progression of tremors is hands →lips→tongue→arms and legs.
    • Hatter's shakes - Severe impairment of daily activities involving delicate movements like shaving, writing, holding a tumbler or spoon.
    • Concussio mercurialis - most severe form, literally no activity is possible.
  • Erethism mercurialis - Shyness, memory loss, and change in personality
  • Nephrotic syndrome and renal tubular anomalies
  • Acrodynia (pink disease) - Seen in small children and characterized by a generalized rash; edema and erythema of the palms, soles, and face. 

Related Pearl: Mercury Poisoning

Features

Mercury
Source of exposure

Thermometers (elemental mercury)

Industries (inorganic mercury)

Fish (organic mercury) 
Route of absorption

Elemental - Respiratory tract (negligible through GI unless the mucosa is damaged) 

Inorganic - GI tract

Organic - GI tract
Mechanism of action

binds to sulhydryl groups of enzymes and affects

  • glutathione metabolism
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

Respiratory tract (elemental mercury)

GI tract (inorganic mercury)

Respiratory + GI tract (organic mercury)
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Renal (elemental mercury)

Renal (inorganic mercury)

CNS (organic mercury)
Characteristic clinical findings

 

Mnemonic: MEATS

M -

  • Mercuria lentis
  • Membranous colitis 
  • Minimata disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy

E-Erethism (personality disturbance, insomnia, and loss of memory)

A-Acrodynia (Pink disease)

T-Tremors (Coarse tremors) - Include Danbury tremors, hatter’s or Glass blower’s shakes

S-Salivation (excessive salivation)
Diagnosis Blood and/or 24 hour urine mercury level
Treatment BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A woman with BRCA1 gene mutation presented with lumps in both breasts and enlarged axillary lymphadenopathy. She gives a history of breast cancer in her sister. MRI and trucut biopsy done confirmed the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia
It is a slow growing tumor
Tamoxifen can be used in the treatment
Has poorer prognosis than invasive lobular carcinoma

questions.solution:
Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the cancer cells to the lymph nodes. 

Medullary carcinoma is a common type of breast cancer associated with BRCA1 gene mutation. Bilateral tumors are common when family history is present. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due to necrosis and hemorrhage. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative (ER/PR/Her-2 negative).

Histopathology consists of:

  • A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells
  • A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation

It has a better prognosis than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of dislocation of the hip?
questions.solution:
The posterior dislocation is the most common type of dislocation of the hip.

 There are three types of dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior - seen in motor vehicle accidents where the flexed knee of the passenger hits the dashboard
  • Anterior - seen in high energy injuries when the patient falls from the height
  • Central - seen when there is a blow over the greater trochanter or fall on the side

questions.text: Carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to _____
questions.solution:
The carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to pulse pressure. They fire more rapidly to a constantly changing pressure than a stationary one.  

Baroreceptors

  1. Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels
  2. Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  3. Afferents
    • Carotid sinus – a branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor – a branch of the Vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve
  4. Center for Reflex
    • Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius)
  5. Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature
    • Most sensitive to pulsatile pressure: They work to maintain BP in the range of mean BP, but it is the changes in the pressure they are the most sensitive to. 
    • The threshold for excitation: 50 mmHg
    • Maximal activity: 180 mmHg
  6. Responses when one carotid sinus is isolated and perfused and the other baroreceptors are denervated
    • Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg:no response
    • 70–110mm Hg: the linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BP and HR
    • >150mm Hg: no further increase in response to the degree of inhibition of the sympathetic nerve is maximal.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the culture of Trypanosoma?
questions.solution:
NNN (Novy, McNeal, and Nicolle) medium is used for the culture of Trypanosoma brucie and cruzie. It is also used for the culture of Leishmania.

The other media used in the culture of Trypanosoma are Weinman's medium and Tobie's medium.

Other options:

Options B, C & D: Boeck and Drbohlav medium, Craig’s medium and NIH polygenic medium are used for the culture of E.histolytica.

questions.text: Fetal posterior cerebral artery (PCA) refers to _______

choices.text: PCA arising from Internal Carotid Artery

questions.solution:
Fetal posterior cerebral artery refers to PCA, arising from the internal carotid artery (ICA).

Normally, the basilar artery divides in the interpeduncular fossa to form two PCAs. PCA arising from ICA is called fetal PCA. 

If the embryonic posterior communicating artery fails to regress, the dominant blood supply to the occipital lobes comes from the ICA via the fetal PCA instead of from the vertebrobasilar system.

Image: CT angiogram showing bilateral fetal posterior cerebral arteries (arrows). The arrowheads indicate the superior cerebellar arteries.

questions.text: Identify the angle shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle, formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 

Causes for pain/tenderness at the costovertebral angle include:

  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction
  • Pyelonephritis
  • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) - caused by Hantavirus.

questions.text: In which of the following is major basic protein seen?
questions.solution:
The major basic protein is the predominant constituent of the crystalline core of the eosinophil granule.

It is also called proteoglycan-2 and is encoded by the PRG2 gene. This protein is involved in: 

  • Antiparasitic defense mechanisms - functions as a cytotoxin and helminthotoxin 
  • Immune hypersensitivity reactions
  • Lysis of epithelial cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests?

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.solution:
Non-parametric tests are tests that do not assume that the data is normally distributed. Thus, they are used for skewed (asymmetric) distributions {skewed either to the lesser side (left-sided skewed) or towards the greater side (right-sided skewed)}.

The chi-square test is an example of a non-parametric test that is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

ANOVA is an example of a parametric test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: In the pressure–volume graph shown below, compliance of lung is represented by _________.
questions.solution:
In the given pressure–volume graph:

  • A – Compliance of chest
  • B – Compliance of lung
  • C – Compliance of lung and chest wall 

The equilibrium position is at functional residual capacity (FRC), where the expanding force on the chest wall is exactly equal to the collapsing force on the lungs. FRC is also known as relaxation volume and represents the amount of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

At the point where volume= FRC,

  • Intraalveolar pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure and considered as zero.
  • Intrapleural pressure is negative (-2.5 mmHg)
  • Transpulmonary pressure = Intraalveolar pressure – intrapleural pressure = 0 – (-2.5 mmHg) = +2.5 mmHg.  

For compliance of lung – Pressure considered is Transpulmonary pressure. So at FRC, Transpulmonary pressure is positive (+2.5 mmHg). Hence, B indicates compliance of lung.  

For compliance of chest wall – Pressure considered is intrapleural – atmospheric pressure. At FRC, this value is -2.5 mmHg. Hence, A represents compliance of the chest wall.  

When the volume is FRC, the combined lung and chest-wall curve intersects the X-axis at an airway pressure of zero. Hence, C represents the combined chest wall and lung compliance.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless ulcer on his penis. A Wasserman test is done and is reactive. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Wassermann's reaction is an example of a complement fixation test. It is a non-specific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. 

An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).

questions.text: An intravenous pyelogram done for evaluation of recurrent UTI in a  child is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Associated with an increased incidence of renal cell carcinoma
Lies just below the origin of inferior mesenteric artery
Division at the level of the isthmus improves function

questions.solution:
The given scenario with intravenous pyelogram showing flower vase sign points to a diagnosis of horseshoe kidney. Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is usually not indicated. This is because it can lead to an increased risk of urinary fistula.

Horseshoe kidneys are the most common fusion defects of the kidney, characterized by abnormalities in the position, rotation, and vascular supply of the kidney.

The fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery. Adrenal glands remain in the normal position. 

There is a 2:1 male predominance. It is also commonly associated with renal cell carcinoma, Wilms tumor, multicystic dysplastic kidney, and Turner’s syndrome.

Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with:

  • Dull renal pain
  • Abdominal lump
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Increased angulation of ureters resulting in - 
    • Nephrolithiasis
    • Hydronephrosis

Radiological diagnosis is by intravenous pyelogram which shows flower vase sign or handshake sign.

Symptomatic management is preferred. Heminephrectomy is usually not indicated for horseshoe kidneys with unilateral RCC/ Wilms tumor. This is because it can result in devascularisation due to the unpredictable blood supply of the horseshoe kidney from nearby major vessels.

Note: Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is only indicated in the course of surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

The below CECT shows a fusion defect of the kidneys.

questions.text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the migrating motor complex.

The image shows 3 phases: 

  • Phase I - quiescent period
  • Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity
  • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity

This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal.

Option A: Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front.

Option B: Segmentation and mixing help in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption.  

It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward.

Option D: Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below.

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements about carotid body tumor except

choices.text: It is seen in people who live at high altitude
10% patients have a positive family history
Carotid angiogram shows splaying of the carotid bifurcation

questions.solution:
Carotid body tumors/ chemodectoma are not hormonally active and the tumors are usually benign.

High yield points

  • It occurs in people who live at high altitude
  • Occur in the 5th decade,10% have family history
  • Slowly growing
  • Carotid angiogram shows Lyre sign (splaying of the carotid bifurcation)

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids has an imino ring?
questions.solution:
Proline is an amino acid with an imino ring.

The distinctive cyclic structure of the side chain of proline gives it exceptional conformational rigidity as compared to other amino acids. Hence, proline plays a major role in collagen stability.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhea and poor appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is the most common cancer associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of celiac disease. Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is the most common cancer associated with celiac disease.

Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also associated with celiac disease.

Celiac disease or celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy is triggered by the ingestion of gluten, which is the major storage protein of wheat and similar grains. It usually affects the 2nd part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. 

Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: 

  • Anti-gliadin antibodies
  • Anti tissue transglutaminase antibodies
  • Anti endomysial antibodies

MARSH's score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis occurs in about 10% of patients with celiac disease.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents with a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition and does not move with protrusion of the tongue. The biopsy of the frozen section is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the given histopathological image showing uniform sheets of cells with capsular invasion by tumor cells is suggestive of follicular carcinoma thyroid.

The following images show follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option A: In follicular adenoma, there is no capsular invasion.

Option C: Anaplastic carcinoma is associated with rapidly progressive swelling with obstructive features and undifferentiated cells on histopathology.

Option D: In medullary carcinoma, amyloid stroma is seen on histopathology.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor?

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last three pregnancies

questions.solution:
Heart disease is currently not considered a contraindication for the induction of labor. Vaginal delivery is preferred in such patients.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: Who is known as the first true epidemiologist in the history of medicine?
questions.solution:
Hippocrates is known as the first true epidemiologist in the history of medicine. He is also known as the father of medicine.

He introduced the concept of the relationship between the environment and human health.  He was the author of Airs, Water, and Places, a treatise on social medicine and hygiene as well as the Corpus Hippocraticum, a collection of 72 volumes of clinical case histories.

He also developed the Hippocratic Oath, which is considered the keystone of medical ethics.

Scientist/ Doctor

Achievements

Father of Indian Surgery

Father of Plastic and Cosmetic Surgery

Author of “Susruta Samhita”

questions.text: In a patient who has completed the 3rd stage of labor following vaginal delivery, what is the minimum amount of blood loss required for her to be diagnosed with postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) in vaginal delivery is defined as a blood loss of more than 500 ml after completion of the third stage of labour.

In Caesarean section, blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract is called PPH.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be:

  • Minor (<1L)
  • Major (>1L)
  • Severe (>2L)

In most cases, the magnitude of haemorrhage cannot be assessed accurately as visual estimates are unreliable.

Note: as per the latest ACOG guidelines, PPH is defined as cumulative blood loss ≥1000 mL or bleeding associated with hypovolaemia in the first 24 hours after birth, irrespective of the route of delivery. It is added that despite the new definition, blood loss >500 mL in a vaginal delivery should raise suspicion and mandates further evaluation.

questions.text: What is the surveillance reporting system used by the WHO?
questions.solution:
The surveillance reporting system used by the WHO is the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

The WHO collects and disseminates epidemiological information on diseases subject to International Health Regulations. It is done through an Automatic Telex Reply Service (ATRS) and the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates severe sensorineural hearing loss as a consequence of untreated suppurative labyrinthitis and Rinne's test is a false negative in this case.

Initially, the patient had a positive fistula test, which implies that the labyrinth is still functioning. Rinne's test is positive which could be due to normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss.

Currently, the patient has a negative fistula test which implies that the labyrinth is dead. This is an example of severe sensorineural hearing loss and here, Rinne test is a false negative.

If intermittent pressure applied to the external ear produces vertigo and nystagmus, it is a positive fistula test. The pressure changes in the external ear are transmitted to the labyrinth. This is suggestive of abnormal communication between the middle ear and the inner ear.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the non-coding regulatory RNAs?

choices.text: Transcribed from protein-coding regions of DNA and translated to regulatory proteins
Transcribed from protein-coding regions of DNA but never translated
Transcribed from non-protein-coding regions of DNA and translated to regulatory proteins
Transcribed from non-protein-coding regions of DNA but never translated

questions.solution:
The non-coding regulatory RNAs are the functional non-protein-coding regions of the DNA, which are transcribed to RNA but are never translated into proteins.

The two important types of non-coding regulatory RNAs are the micro RNA (miRNA) and the long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs). These RNAs play an important role in the regulation of gene expression.

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.

It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference.

Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc.

Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presented with complaints of dull pain over the right lower abdomen for the past 2  months. CT scan revealed a left-sided multiloculated adnexal mass and exploratory laparotomy showed small mucoid implants scattered in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and findings point to a diagnosis of pseudomyxoma peritonei. It is associated with mucinous cystadenoma.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare clinical entity characterized by diffuse intra-abdominal gelatinous and mucoid material on peritoneal surfaces. Spontaneous perforation of a mucinous cystadenoma leads to implantation of low-grade malignant tumor cells in the peritoneum.

However, the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei is carcinoma of the appendix.

Diagnosis is by CT, MRI, and laparoscopy. Even after the removal of the ovarian tumor, these cells continue to secrete mucin. Recurrence rates are high.

questions.text: An immunologist orders a nitroblue tetrazolium test on a child suspected to have a primary immunodeficiency disease. What condition is she screening the child for?
questions.solution:
The Nitroblue Tetrazolium Test (NBT) is used as a screening test for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) by assessing the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in phagocytes.

This principle relies on the color change of nitroblue tetrazolium, which transforms from colorless/yellow to deep blue when it encounters ROS. A higher nitroblue test score indicates that the cell is more efficient in producing ROS.

In chronic granulomatous disease, there is an NADPH oxidase defect. Hence, the phagocyte cannot produce reactive oxygen species or radicals required for bacterial killing, which results in recurrent infections. Here, the leukocytes fail to reduce nitroblue tetrazolium during phagocytosis. Hence, a negative test (NBT remains colourless to yellow) is seen in CGD.

A positive test result means neutrophils turn blue, as shown below: 

A negative test means nitroblue tetrazolium remains colourless/yellow, as shown below: 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: A sexually active woman who was using barrier contraceptives is planning on switching to DMPA injectables. Which of the following is the correct dosage of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
The dosage for injectable depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is 150 mg every 3 months.

It acts by:

  • Bringing changes in the cervical mucus
  • Making the endometrium hostile
  • Preventing ovulation

Disadvantages include spotting and intermediate per vaginal bleeding.

Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas.

questions.text: A newly married woman was found dead in her house. On inquiry, it was informed by the neighbours that the couple used to fight a lot regarding dowry. Which section deals with this scenario?
questions.solution:
Dowry Death is defined under section 80 of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) 2023 (IPC 304B).

  • If a husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage, they shall be deemed to have caused her death.
  • The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 63 (IPC 375) deals with rape.

Option C: Section 72 (IPC 228A) deals with imprisonment for up to 2 years and a fine for disclosure of the identity of a rape victim.

Option D: Section 100 (IPC 299) deals with culpable homicide.

questions.text: An infant delivered at full-term by normal vaginal delivery, presented with respiratory distress immediately after birth. Chest X-ray showed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The common clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Dextrocardia
  • Scaphoid abdomen

Prenatal diagnosis is done by ultrasonography. Lung-to-head ratio (LHR) is used to assess severity in patients with left-sided CDH. An LHR value of <1 is associated with a very poor prognosis, whereas an LHR >1.4 predicts a more favourable outcome.

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the aspiration of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which can occur before, during or immediately after birth. Meconium is the first intestinal discharge from newborns, a viscous, dark-green substance composed of intestinal epithelial cells, lanugo, mucus, and intestinal secretions.

Option D: During normal delivery, the compression of the rib cage while passing through the mother's vaginal canal helps to remove fluid from the lungs. However, newborns who are delivered via cesarean birth may have excess fluid in the lungs and therefore be hypoxic and develop transient tachypnea.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: In children, what is the most common cause of suprasellar enlargement with calcification?
questions.solution:
Childhood craniopharyngioma is the most common cause of suprasellar enlargement with calcification in children.

Craniopharyngioma is a relatively benign neoplasm that typically arises in the suprasellar region. They are derived from Rathke pouch  and have bimodal age distribution. Calcification is a characteristic feature of childhood craniopharyngioma.

The image is a CT showing craniopharyngioma with calcified cystic structure in the suprasellar region, along with hydrocephalus.

 

The two variants of craniopharyngioma are:

  • Adamantinomatous - It is seen in children. Calcification is characteristic of this variety.
  • Papillary - It is seen in adults. Wet keratin nodules are the characteristic histologic feature of this type.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma is one of the commonest infratentorial tumors in childhood. It is a WHO-grade 1 benign tumor and does not show calcification.

Option C: Rathke cleft cyst shows no solid or enhancing component. Calcification is rare. It is unilocular and the majority are completely or mostly intrasellar.

Option D: Suprasellar tuberculoma appears as a calcified mass in the suprasellar region with perilesional edema and obstructive hydrocephalous.

A three-year-old should normally be able to walk upstairs with alternate feet.

questions.text:
A 50 year old man died of an unknown condition. On autopsy, a sample of the brain was taken as a specimen, and the following fibres were seen on microscopic examination.
These fibres are not seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of rosenthal fibres. Rosenthal fibres are not seen in Pick's disease.

Rosenthal fibers are thick, elongated, brightly eosinophilic, irregular structures that occur within astrocytic processes. They contain two heat­shock proteins (αB ­crystallin and HSP27) as well as ubiquitin.They are typically found in regions of longstanding gliosis and are characteristic of a type of glial tumor—pilocytic astrocytoma.

Alexander disease is a leukodystrophy associated with mutations in the gene encoding GFAP. In this condition, abundant rosenthal fibers are found in periventricular, perivascular, and subpial locations.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient diagnosed with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome was prescribed a drug with NMDA antagonist activity. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Felbamate is the NMDA receptor antagonist prescribed to this patient. It also potentiates GABA action. It is indicated in refractory primary or secondary generalized seizures and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

Felbamate is associated with aplastic anemia and liver failure.

Option A: Memantine is used in Alzheimer’s disease.

Option B: Riluzole is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Option C: Ketamine causes dissociative anesthesia and used in general anesthesia.

questions.solution:
Acid phosphatase is not a marker of kidney injury.

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive patient is diagnosed with bilateral renal artery stenosis. He is also on treatment for diabetes mellitus. Which among the following drugs would be the most appropriate for him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, verapamil would be the most appropriate drug for the management of hypertension in the patient as it has no adverse effect on glycemic control.

Option A: Efferent arteriolar constriction maintains the glomerular filtration pressure in bilateral renal artery stenosis. ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral renal stenosis as it can precipitate acute renal failure due to dilation of efferent arterioles and fall in glomerular filtration pressure.

Options C and D: Beta-blockers and thiazides can worsen glycemic control and are not suitable in the given scenario.

questions.text: Following autopsy, an H&E stained specimen of the lung was obtained which is given below. What could be the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary arteriole which is characteristically seen in amniotic fluid embolism(AFE).

AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins.

Findings at autopsy include:

  • Presence in the maternal pulmonary micro-vasculature of-
    • Squamous cells shed from fetal skin
    • Lanugo hair
    • Fat from vernix caseosa
    • Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract 
  • Marked pulmonary edema
  • Diffuse alveolar damage
  • Presence of fibrin thrombi in many vascular beds due to DIC

questions.text: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness.

Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates right-sided conductive deafness or left-sided sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne's test is positive on both the ears, conductive deafness can be ruled out and hence, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding sirtuins?
questions.solution:
Sirtuins are responsible for an increase in insulin sensitivity. Hence, it can play an important role in the treatment of diabetes.

Sirtuins are a class of proteins that possess either mono-ADP-ribosyltransferase or deacylase activity. They have been shown to slow down the aging process. Calorie restriction and intake of red wine are associated with an increase in sirtuin levels.

Sirtuins act by the following mechanisms:

  • Inhibition of the metabolic activity
  • Reduction in apoptosis 
  • Stimulation of protein folding 
  • Inhibition of free radical damage 
  • Increased insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism
  • Ensure that damaged DNA is not propagated, preventing the accumulation of mutations
  • Promotes replicative senescence under chronic stress

questions.text: The Indian Association of Paediatrics is organizing a workshop on neonatal resuscitation. Which of the following best describes this program?

choices.text: Discussion of 4-8 experts in front of an audience
Series of four or more interactive meetings
Series of speeches on a given subject

questions.solution: A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group, using external consultants or experts. It helps increase individual efficiency as a professional worker.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is hospitalized with pneumonia. He is a known patient of type 2 diabetes. During the hospital stay, his appetite is poor and his oral intake is irregular. The physician decides to administer rapid-acting insulin based on high blood sugar values. Which of the following would he use?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario describes the sliding scale method. Rapid-acting insulins such as glulisine are used.

Sliding scale refers to the administration of insulin as a bolus dose based on the blood sugar level before the meal. Using this principle, the insulin dose is titrated every time according to pre-meal glucose levels to determine insulin requirement. Hence, rapid-acting insulin is preferred.

This method requires a fixed carbohydrate intake at every meal. It is used for the short-term management of hospitalized patients, especially when the frequency or quantity of food intake is very variable.

It does not deliver insulin in a physiological manner, hence is not a preferred long-term strategy for glycemic control.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with urethral discharge is treated with the grey kit. This treatment is effective for the control of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The grey kit is effective for the treatment of infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a seizure episode. His wife says that he has been very drowsy and has not passed urine for the past 2 days. Investigations reveal serum urea of 71 mg/dl and creatinine of 5.6 mg/dl. He is referred for urgent hemodialysis. You would take all of the following precautions except:

choices.text: Removing more fluid during the beginning than the end of the procedure
Maintaining fluid removal rate below 13 mL/kg/hour

questions.solution:
Cooling, not warming, the dialysate before dialysis must be done to prevent hypotension during dialysis.

Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The mechanism is not fully understood and occurs due to multiple factors. However, the following precautions have been shown to frequently prevent this complication:

  • Careful calculation of the dry weight and adjustment of the filtration rate accordingly.
  • Ultrafiltration modeling such that more fluid is removed during the beginning than the end of the procedure.
  • Avoiding rapid fluid removal and maintaining the rate < 13 mL/kg/hour.
  • Avoiding heavy meals during dialysis.
  • Cooling of the dialysate during the dialysis.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures formed during the development of the definitive notochord, from the earlier stage to the later stage.

1. Notochordal plate
2. Notochordal process
3. Blastopore
4. Notochordal canal
questions.solution:
The correct order is blastopore - notochordal process - notochordal canal - notochordal plate - definitive notochord.

Notochord formation steps:

  • Primitive knot - The cranial end of the primitive streak thickens to form the primitive knot (primitive node or Hensen's node).
  • Primitive pit (Blastopore) - A depression appears in the center of the knot known as the primitive pit (or blastopore).
  • Notochordal process - The cells in the primitive knot multiply and pass cranially in the midline between the ectoderm and endoderm. They reach up to the caudal margin of the prechordal plate. These cells form a solid chord known as the notochordal process or head process.
  • Notochordal canal - The cavity of the blastopore then extends into the notochordal process to form a tube-like structure called the notochordal canal.
  • Notochordal plate - The floor of the notochordal canal gets intercalated (mixed up) with the endoderm and gradually breaks down. This eventually leads to the formation of a flat plate-like structure notochordal plate.
  • Definitive notochord - The cells from the notochordal plate proliferate to form a solid rod-like structure called a definitive notochord.

questions.text: The zero reference point is ____.

choices.text: Neutral point between positive and negative end of all vectors.

questions.solution:
The zero reference point is the negative end of all vectors.

A vector is an arrow that points in the direction of the flow of current in the heart with the arrowhead in a positive direction. Additionally, by convention, the length of the arrow is drawn proportional to the voltage of the potential.

As the impulse spreads through the myocardium, the vector of current flow changes rapidly both in length (due to the changes in voltage) and the direction (due to the change in the average direction of the electrical potential in the heart). These changes are depicted in a vectorcardiogram. The negative end of all vectors is considered the zero reference point in vectorcardiograms by convention.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with a single episode of loss of consciousness. He was about to give a speech at his graduation ceremony when he suddenly turned pale and collapsed to the ground. Which of the following areas contain the nerve responsible for it?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes a vasovagal syncope triggered by a stressful event. The vagus nerve is a content of the carotid triangle marked as 1.

In the given image:

  1. Carotid triangle

  • Veins:
    • Internal jugular vein
    • Common facial vein
    • Lingual vein
  • Nerves:
    • Vagus nerve
    • Hypoglossal nerve
    • Spinal part of accessory
    • Sympathetic chain
    • Ansa cervicalis

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: The following are characteristic features of Staphylococcus food poisoning except

choices.text: Optimum temperature for toxin production is 37°C
Intradietic toxin is responsible for intestinal symptoms
Toxin can be destroyed by boiling for 30 minutes

questions.solution:
Staphylococcal enterotoxin is heat stable. So, cooking the contaminated food and leaving at room temp for some time leads to toxin accumulation. Hence, the statement that toxin can be destroyed by boiling for 30 minutes is incorrect.

About Other Options:

Option a) The optimum temperature for toxin production is the same as the optimum temperature for S. aureus growth, i.e., at  37°C.

Note - Optimum temperature for pigment production is 22°C and for MRSA expression is 30°C.

Option b) Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin is intradietic in nature, i.e., it is preformed, secreted in the diet

Option d) Incubation period of S. aureus food poisoning is 1-6 hours.

questions.text:
Match the following types of calcifications with the diseases they are associated with.
Type of calcification Disease
A. Popcorn calcification i) Fibrocystic disease
B. Lead- pipe calcification ii) Duct ectasia
C. Broken needle calcification iii) Traumatic fat necrosis
D. Tea- cup calcification iv) Fibroadenoma
questions.solution:
Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.

Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis.

questions.text: Identify the third-generation beta-blocker that does not cause alpha 1 receptor antagonism.
questions.solution:
Celiprolol is a third-generation beta blocker having no action on α1 receptors. It causes vasodilation by partial selective β2 agonist activity.

Labetalol, carvedilol, and bucindolol are non-selective third-generation beta blockers that possess additional α1 receptor antagonistic action. This is responsible for their vasodilatory effect.

Note: Third-generation β-blockers are those that possess additional vasodilating actions and include cardioselective and non-selective drugs.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: MEN4 syndrome is caused by a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
MEN4 is caused by genetic mutations in CDKN1B (cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor), located on chromosome 12.

MEN1 is caused due to MEN1 gene mutation on chromosome 11.

MEN2 is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutation on chromosome 10.

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: The O2-CO2 diagram shown below shows a ventilation-perfusion ratio curve for the normal lung. Which of the following options best describes the effect of decreasing the ventilation-perfusion ratio on the alveolar Po2 and Pco2?
questions.solution:
Decreased ventilation-perfusion ratio implies decreased oxygenation due to decreased ventilation with respect to perfusion. Hence, PAO2 decreases and Pco2 increases.

A decrease in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (VA/Q) is depicted by moving to the left along the normal ventilation-perfusion line as shown in the figure (Zones here refer to the zones of variation in pulmonary blood flow and alveolar ventilation under influence of gravity)

  • Zone 1 - Zone 1 has the lowest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 3 but, in Zone 1 Ventilation (V)>>Perfusion (Q) hence V­/Q­ is high
    • PAO2 is highest
    • PACO2 is lowest
  • Zone 2 -  Ventilation (V) almost equal to Perfusion (Q) but slightly lower so V/Q is average (~0.8)
  • Zone 3 - Zone 3 has the highest ventilation compared to Zones 2 and 1 but, in Zone 3 Perfusion (Q) >> Ventilation (V) hence V­/Q­ is low 
    • PAO2 is lowest
    • PACO2 is highest.

*PAO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of oxygen

*PACO2 - Alveolar partial pressure of CO2

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of crushing chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. It starts whenever he has ice cream and he takes sublingual nitroglycerin which provides him relief. He underwent manometry which showed simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with episodes triggered by cold foods and manometric findings are suggestive of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus. It is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It is more common in women. 

Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles. It is often triggered by cold foods. It mimics symptoms of myocardial infarction and also shows improvement when sublingual nitroglycerin is administered. It causes smooth muscle relaxation of the esophagus. 

A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. However, manometry (high-resolution manometry is preferred) is the gold standard test for diagnosis. In classic manometry, if there are simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) it is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.

On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (distal contractile integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. The distal contractile integral (DCI) is an index of contractile vigor in high-resolution manometry, calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter - It is achalasia in evolution. Shows increased LES pressure but normal peristalsis.

Nutcracker’s esophagus - In conventional manometry, it shows a high-amplitude peristaltic contraction ( >180mmHg) and a longer duration of contraction (>7sec).

In high-resolution manometry, a DCI > 8000mmHg is suggestive of nutcracker's esophagus.

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

100% failed peristalsis

(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text: Which of the following complications during pregnancy does not increase the risk of PPH?
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios does not increase the risk of PPH. However, polyhydramnios can increase the risk by causing uterine atony, due to an overdistended uterus.

Risk factors for primary PPH:

Atonic PPH:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Traumatic PPH:

  • Instrumental delivery
  • Episiotomy
  • Precipitate labour
  • Macrosomia

Coagulopathy:

  • Sepsis
  • IUD
  • HELLP syndrome

Causes of secondary PPH:

  • Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes
  • Endometritis
  • Abnormal involution of placental site
  • Secondary haemorrhage from Caesarean section wound
  • Placental polyp
  • Infected fibroid
  • Uterine av fistula
  • Puerperal uterine inversion
  • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: Which of the following image shows the Duncan method?
questions.solution:
Image B shows the Duncan method of placental separation. 
 

Comparison between two types of placental separation methods:

Schultze method Duncan method
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labour. 

One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwards and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.

Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the placenta covers the internal os partially i.e. it covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of norgestimate OCPs?
questions.solution:
Norgestimate is one of the 3rd generation progesterone agents. All OCPs have the disadvantage of increasing the risk of venous thrombosis. 

Third-generation progesterone agents are less androgenic and so reduce the occurrence of acne and hirsutism. They also have a lower risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders compared to the previous generation progesterone agents.

Benefits of combined pills:

  • Effective contraceptive
  • Useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhoea
  • Relieves dysmenorrhoea and premenstrual tension
  • Prevents anaemia by reducing the menstrual loss
  • Lower incidence of benign breast neoplasia (fibrocystic disease), functional ovarian cyst, ovarian and uterine malignancy
  • Reduced risk of PID - due to thick cervical mucus caused by progestogen, preventing the organisms from entering into the uterine cavity 
  • Reduced incidence of ectopic pregnancy - due to suppression of ovulation and decreased risk of PID
  • Protects against rheumatoid arthritis
  • Reduces the risk of anorectal cancer
  • Useful in acne, PCOD, and endometriosis

Related Pearl: Types of monophasic combined oral pills

2nd Generation Ethinyl oestradiol Norgestrel, LNG
3rd Generation Ethinyl oestradiol Desogestrel,gestodene norgestimate
