(Yasmin)		 Ethinyl oestradiol Drospirenone

questions.text: Phenylalanine is the precursor of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Phenylalanine is not a precursor of melatonin.

Serotonin is the precursor of melatonin and is derived from tryptophan.

The derivatives of phenylalanine are:

  • Tyrosine → Thyroxine
  • Dopa → Melanin
  • Dopamine
  • Nor-epinephrine
  • Epinephrine

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: What is the adult representation of the location of anterior neuropore?
questions.solution:
The location of the anterior neuropore is represented in adults as lamina terminalis. 

The anterior neuropore closes around the 25th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the lamina terminalis. The lamina terminalis forms the anterior boundary of the third ventricle.

The posterior neuropore closes around the 28th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the terminal ventricle. The terminal ventricle is present in the proximal 5 to 6 mm of filum terminale.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with the following finding. Weakness of which of the following muscles could not have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and image is suggestive of uterine prolapse which occurs due to weakness of the levator ani muscle. Ischiococcygeus is not a part of the levator ani. It is a separate muscle that lies at the posterosuperior part of the pelvis and is not a part of the supports of the uetrus.

The levator ani forms a large portion of the pelvic floor. It is composed of three separate paired muscles:

  • Pubococcygeus - this starts from the posterior part of the pubis and runs lateral to the urethra and it' spinchter while passing through the pelvic floor.
  • Puborectalis - This muscle starts from the ischiopubic rami and runs medial to pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus to terminate posterior to the rectum at anorectal junction. 
  • Iliococcygeus - This muscle is placed posterior most as a triangular musculotendinous sheet where the apex is attached to the tip of the ischial spine and the base is attached to the lateral margin of coccyx and the fifth sacral segment.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: CT scan of a patient is being reviewed. Identify the given pathology.
questions.solution:
The CT shows an air-fluid level with floating membranes (marked using yellow arrows in the image below) characteristic of a hydatid cyst. It is called a water lily or camalote sign. The most common location of hydatid cysts is the liver, followed by the lung.

If there is a disruption of the inner layers, it results in a cavitary lesion with one or more of the following radiographic features:

  • Air-fluid level
  • Water lily sign/ camalote sign - air-fluid level with a floating membrane 
  • Double wall
  • Rising sun sign/ serpent sign - a double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom 
  • Empty cyst sign - when all the contents are removed

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus species and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body. Echinococcus granulosus species is the most common.

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. Where should she start marking the cervical dilatation?
questions.solution:
In a partograph, the first marking of cervical dilatation should be made on the left of the alert line. In a normal partograph, the plotting remains on the left of the alert line.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the below image.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a bacterial corneal ulcer with hypopyon.

Hypopyon in a bacterial ulcer:

  • It is due to the outpouring of leucocytes from the vessels and their gravitation to the bottom of the anterior chamber to form a hypopyon.
  • Sterile: Consists of leucocytes
  • Mobile

questions.text: What is the most common parotid gland tumor?
questions.solution:
The most common tumor of the parotid gland is a pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma is a painless, slowly growing, benign tumor that usually affects females more than males. It most commonly arises from the superficial lobe. It is unicentric in origin with a pseudo-capsule present. It is a radioresistant tumor

Clinical features:

  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency
  • Well-defined margins
  • Free from deeper structures
  • With no facial nerve involvement

In case of deep lobe involvement- tonsils and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 44-year-old construction worker, who is a known case of sarcoidosis, has now presented with polyuria, constipation, and myalgia for the past 5 days. An ECG was taken which showed a short QT interval. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?��������������������� ���������������������� ����������

choices.text: Increased production of PTH related peptide

questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with a short QT interval points towards hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia in a patient with sarcoidosis is due to the increased production of vitamin D by the non-caseating granulomas. 

Hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria are seen in some patients with sarcoidosis. The increased production of vitamin D (1,25-dihydoxyvitamin D) results in increased intestinal absorption of calcium, leading to hypercalcemia.

Vitamin D supplementation and increased sun exposure in patients with sarcoidosis can precipitate hypercalcemia.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: The site in the pharyngeal arch where the ectodermal cleft meets the endodermal pouch is known as:
questions.solution:
The pharyngeal membrane is the location where the ectoderm of the pharyngeal cleft meets the endoderm of the pharyngeal pouch. 

In the interval between any two adjoining pharyngeal arches, the endoderm extends outward in the form of a pouch (pharyngeal pouch) to meet the ectoderm, which dips into this interval as a pharyngeal cleft. The membrane formed where the pharyngeal cleft comes in contact with the pouch is called the pharyngeal membrane. 

Initially, there are four pharyngeal membranes between the five arches. Only the first pharyngeal membrane develops and contributes to the formation of the tympanic membrane. The 2nd, 3th, and 4th pharyngeal membranes do not develop further into any structure. They get obliterated when the mesoderm from the 2nd arch overgrows and fills the succeeding clefts.

questions.text: A young woman delivered her baby on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you notice a perineal tear. This injury could have been prevented by all except:

choices.text: Slow delivery of the head in between contractions

questions.solution:
Perineal injury cannot be prevented in normal labor by routine timely episiotomy. Routine episiotomy is associated with an increased incidence of disruption of anal sphincters and rectal tears.

Indications of episiotomy:

  • Shoulder dystocia
  • Breech delivery
  • Fetal macrosomia
  • Operative vaginal deliveries
  • Persistent occiput posterior positions

Methods of prevention of perineal laceration:

  • Avoid delivery by early extension
  • Deliver head in between contractions
  • Perform timely episiotomy when indicated (not routine).

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the given otoscopy finding in a child with poor scholastic performance?
questions.solution:
The given otoscopic image shows a subtotal perforation. It involves all four quadrants of the tympanic membrane but is covered by remnant pars tensa/annulus all around.

Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the single most important cause of hearing impairment in rural populations. Children with CSOM have poor academic performance. 

Related Pearl: Types of tympanic membrane perforation

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at her house. How many visits should an ASHA worker make post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, where the woman has had a home delivery, an ASHA worker would make 7 visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother.

Home visits of ASHA workers post delivery:

  • 7 visits after home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 5 visits after cesarean section delivery, first visit on day 7, and thereafter 4 visits till day 42

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: Yuzpe's regimen of emergency contraception consists of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Yuzpe's regimen of emergency contraception consists of a combination of levonorgestrel and ethinylestradiol.

The regimen includes two doses at 12 hours intervals within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It has a higher incidence of nausea and vomiting and is less efficacious than progesterone only standard regimen.

Methods of Emergency contraception:

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel 0.75mg stat and after 12 hours
Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + Norgestrel 0.25 mg 2 tab stat and 2 tab after 12 hours
Conjugated estrogen 15 mg BD x 5 days
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5 mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUDs Insertion within 5-7 days after accidental unprotected exposure.Not suitable for rape victims
Centchroman 2 tablets(60 mg) to be taken twice at an interval  of 12 hours within 24 hours of intercourse.
Ulipristal 30 mg within 120 hours

questions.text: The elimination after 3 half-lives in first-order kinetics is around:
questions.solution:
The proportion of drug eliminated after three half-lives in first-order kinetics is around 87.5%. 

After each half-life, 50% of the drug is eliminated or the plasma concentration becomes half the original value.

Therefore, after, 

  • 1 half-life = 50% drug is eliminated
  • 2 half-lives = 75% drug is eliminated
  • 3 half-lives = 87.5% is eliminated
  • 4 half-lives = 93% is eliminated

Thus, about 4-5 half lives are required for near-complete drug elimination.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is the gold standard for assessing corneal thickness?
questions.solution:
The gold standard technique for assessing corneal thickness is ultrasound pachymetry, which uses a corneal pachymeter.

Measurement of the corneal thickness (pachymetry) indirectly reflects endothelial function. The average central corneal thickness is around 0.5 mm, which gradually increases toward the periphery to around 0.7 mm. Normally, as a diurnal variation, corneas tend to be slightly thicker just after a person awakes in the morning.

Other options: 

Option A: Confocal microscopy is an imaging technique that allows in vivo examination of corneal structures at high magnification and resolution. It is used to assess corneal nerve morphology and corneal endothelium.

Option B: Keratometry measures the anterior corneal curvature and is traditionally performed with a manual keratometer, also known as an ophthalmometer.

Option D: Corneal topography is used to assess the anterior corneal surface, its shape and thickness. 

The image below shows a corneal pachymeter.

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: An elderly patient who presented with abdominal discomfort and weight loss was diagnosed with type I gastric cancer according to Lauren’s classification. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Type I gastric cancer is associated with hematogenous spread. 

Lauren's system classifies gastric cancer pathology as either type I (intestinal) or type II (diffuse), based on differences in etiology, epidemiology, and pathology. Intestinal type of gastric cancer shows hematogenous spread, whereas diffuse-type shows transmural and lymphatic spread.

questions.text: The immediate response of J receptor stimulation is
questions.solution:
The immediate reflex response of J receptor stimulation is apnea. It is followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension (pulmonary chemoreflex).

Juxtacapillary receptors are the C fiber endings located close to the pulmonary vessels in the alveolar interstitium. They are not involved in quiet or normal respiration. They are stimulated by 

  • Hyperinflation of the lung
  • Intravenous or intracardiac administration of chemicals like capsaicin P

questions.text: The following image shows the resulting wound cavity from a  bullet.  Which of the following explains the shape of the wound cavity?
questions.solution:
The shape of the wound cavity can be explained by yawing of the bullet. 

Yawing is a common phenomenon seen with bullets (not with spheres).  It is used to describe a bullet traveling in an irregular fashion .

The angle between the trajectory and the long axis of the bullet increases due to destabilising forces until it reaches 90 degrees , i.e., the bullet’s long axis is perpendicular to the trajectory. The yawing motion then continues until 180 degrees and the bullet will remain in this stable position where the base is the leading part.

The path of a projectile in a dense medium therefore shows three distinct sections, depending on the respective cross-sectional area:

  • Narrow channel
  • Increased cavities
  • Tail end

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: Hypoxia-induced factors stimulate ___________ cells of the kidney to initiate erythropoiesis.
questions.solution:
Hypoxia induced factors stimulate interstitial cells to initiate erythropoiesis

Erythropoietin is produced by interstitial cells in the peritubular capillary bed of the kidney.

Erythropoietin inturn initiates erythropoiesis

William G. Kaelin Jr., Sir Peter J. Ratcliffe and Gregg L. Semenza won the 2019 Nobel Prize in physiology or medicine. The trio identified molecular machinery that regulates the activity of genes in response to varying levels of oxygen. Their work paved the path for new strategies to fight anemia, cancer and many other diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common eating disorder?
questions.solution:
Binge eating disorder is the most common eating disorder. It is more common in females than males.

During a binge, the patient feels like she cannot control her eating and eats an abnormally large amount of food over a short time. These episodes often occur in private and generally include foods of dense caloric content.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyze the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
The rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis is catalyzed by the enzyme, glycogen phosphorylase.

The process of phosphorolytic cleavage of the α1 → 4 linkages of glycogen to yield single units of glucose 1-phosphate, is catalyzed by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase.

Glycogen phosphorylase requires pyridoxal phosphate as the coenzyme The phosphate group is catalytically active. There are different isoenzymes of glycogen phosphorylase in the liver, muscle, and brain.

questions.text: A patient with a history of parotidectomy presented with sweating over the cheek during meal times. To confirm the diagnosis, the parotid region was painted with dry corn starch, and the patient was asked to chew on a piece of gum. You observe the area changing color as shown below. Which of the following nerves form an aberrant connection here?

choices.text: Auriculotemporal nerve and chorda tympani nerve
Chorda tympani nerve and lingual nerve
Chorda tympani nerve and great auricular nerve
Auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is of Frey's syndrome. The auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve form aberrant connections. 

In starch-iodine test, dry corn starch is applied to the affected area. In presence of gustatory sweating, the affected area turns blue after being exposed to the iodine in sweat. 

Frey's syndrome is also known as gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule.

During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands(great auricular nerve).

This results in sweating, warmth, and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.  

Management:

  • Antiperspirants - aluminium chloride
  • Tympanic neurectomy
  • Botulinum toxin injection into the affected skin

Gustatory sweating is known as Frey’s syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule. During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands (great auricular nerve). This results in sweating, warmth and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria. 

The cell wall of bacteria provides shape and ridigity to the bacterial cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans.

Variety of amino acids Few Several

Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

 

Other options:

Option C: The cell wall of fungi consists of chitin, mannan, and polysaccharides (glucan).

Option D: The cell wall of mycobacteria have mycolic acid, which is responsible for acid fastness.

questions.solution:
Class III drugs: MNEMONIC - BInDAS

B – Bretylium

In – Ibutilide

D – Dofetilide

A - Amiodarone

questions.text: What is the most common tumor arising from undescended testis?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy that occurs in an undescended testis is a seminoma (risk is 5–10 times).

An early orchidopexy is the management of choice because it helps in the early detection of these tumors in the testis as the testis is in the scrotum after the orchidopexy

The other complications that may develop as a result of the undescended testis can be remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion

E- Epididymorchitis

S- Sterility

T- Trauma (Increased risk)

I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: Which of the following methods of antibiotic susceptibility testing cannot be used to calculate the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug?
questions.solution:
Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cannot be calculated using Kirby-Bauer's disk diffusion method and Stokes disk diffusion method as they are semi-quantitative methods.

MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism. Methods to determine MIC include:

  • Tube dilution method
  • Agar dilution method
  • E-test method

World Antimicrobial Awareness Week, Nov 18-24 2022, is a global campaign that is celebrated annually to improve awareness and understanding of antimicrobial resistance and encourage best practices among the public. The theme for this year is “Preventing Antimicrobial Resistance Together” to encourage the prudent use of antimicrobials and to strengthen preventive measures addressing antimicrobial resistance

questions.text: Quantitative infectivity assay of viruses is done by _______.
questions.solution:
Quantitative infectivity assay of viruses is done by plaque assay.

Quantitative assays of viruses can be done by physical and biological methods. Physical methods, like real-time PCR, radioimmunoassays, ELISA, antigen detection assay (hemagglutination) and electron microscopy, give the total number of viral particles in a specimen but cannot differentiate between infectious and non-infectious virus particles. To determine the total number of infectious virus particles in a specimen, biological methods are used. End point biologic assays depend on the measure of animal death, animal infection or cytopathic effects in tissue culture. It is measured as serial dilutions of the virus being tested. Examples include plaque and pock assays.

In the plaque assay, host cell monolayers are inoculated with a viral suspension and are overlaid with medium containing agar or carboxymethylcellulose to prevent virus spreading throughout the culture. After several days, the cells initially infected have produced virus that spreads only to surrounding cells, producing a small area of infection known as plaque. One infectious viral particle forms a single plaque. The image below shows a plaque assay. 

The image below shows pock assay. 

Other options:

Option A: Egg inoculation is a method for the cultivation of viruses. 

Option B: Hemadsorption is a method for the detection of viral growth in cell structures. 

Option D: Electron microscopy is used to determine the total viral count. It cannot differentiate between infectious and non-infectious particles and hence is not a quantitative infectivity assay.

questions.text: The relative protein content of milk is in the order
questions.solution:
Human milk has the lowest protein content of all milk.  

Relative contents of nutrients in different kinds of milk.   

Fat, Protein and energy content: Buffalo>Goat>Cow>Human . 

Lactose - Human>Buffalo>Goat>Cow.      

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A patient with deafness and mental retardation is found to have an excess accumulation of glycosaminoglycans in his body. After a detailed evaluation, he is diagnosed with Hunter disease. What is the site of synthesis of these accumulated substances?
questions.solution:
The sites of synthesis of glycosaminoglycans (GAG) are the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus.

Synthesis of the core proteins occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum, whereas, biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycan chains and their subsequent modifications occurs in the Golgi apparatus

Glycosaminoglycans or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. They may be attached to a protein molecule to form a proteoglycan. Proteoglycans are components of the ground substance of connective tissue. Proteoglycans have a bottle brush appearance.

Note: Hyaluronic acid is the only GAG that is not synthesized by the Golgi apparatus. It is formed at the plasma membrane. It participates in cellular migration among other things.

questions.text: During a field visit, you explain about ideal living standards to the general public. Which of the following is false regarding windows in housing standards?

choices.text: At least 2 windows in each room
At a height more than 5 feet in a living room
One window should open into open space
Window area should be 1/5th of floor area

questions.solution:
The windows in the living room must be at a height of not more than 3 feet above the floor.

Non-Rural Housing Standards in India:

Housing parameters

Description
Site

Elevated to protect from rains and floods.

Independent access to the street.

Away from vector breeding sites and other pollutants like smoke, noise, dust.

The soil on which it is founded must be dry and safe.
Floor A pucca floor that is impermeable, easy to clean, free from cracks, damp-proof. The height of the plinth must be 2 – 3 feet.
Walls 9 inch thick, strong, low heat capacity, weather-resistant, unsuitable for harbourage of rats/vermin.
Roof Height not less than 10 feet (3m).
Rooms The number of rooms must be according to the size of the family. However, the basic number is two.
Floor area A living room should have at least 120 sq. ft. of area for occupancy of more than 1 person and 100 sq. ft. for occupancy of only one person. 50 -100 sq. ft. floor area per person is optimum in a living room.
Cubic space 500 – 1000 cubic feet of air space per capita.
Windows At least 2 windows per room with one opening into an open space. Windows must be at a height of not more than 3 feet above ground. Window area must be 1/5th of floor area.
Lighting Daylight factor should be >1% over half the floor area.
Sanitary privy Every house must have a sanitary privy.
Others Proper facilities for garbage disposal, bathing and washing and a good water supply.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of marking B?

choices.text: Swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp
Appears only several hours after birth

questions.solution:
The area marked B represents a cephalohematoma. It is not a swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.

Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.

Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat the associated hyperbilirubinemia (resorption of blood takes place by the breakdown of RBCs).

 

 

Other markings-

A- Caput succedaneum. It is a diffuse ecchymotic or edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears with the first week of life.

C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures.

D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: A child was being evaluated for an underlying cardiac defect. On auscultation, a murmur was heard which began in systole, enveloped the second heart sound, and continued through some portion of the diastole. Which of the following condition is not associated with this finding?

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation

questions.solution:
The murmur described above is a continuous murmur. 

A continuous murmur is produced when there is a pressure gradient between the cardiac chambers or the blood vessels throughout the systole and diastole. Continous murmurs are characterised by the flow of blood in the same direction and through the same channel during systole and diastole. These murmurs begin in systole, envelope the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole.

Conditions producing a continuous murmur:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Venous hum
  • AV fistula
  • Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm

Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation does not produce a continuous murmur. It produces a systolic-diastolic murmur as the blood flows through different channels during systole and diastole. These murmurs do not envelope S2.

questions.text: A patient with longstanding uncontrolled hypertension has been diagnosed with chronic renal failure. Which of the following will you not expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
CKD itself leads to a reduction in potassium excretion, causing its buildup. Thus, hypokalemia is not expected in a patient with CKD.

The measures used in the management of CKD and its associated complications include:

  • Antihypertensive therapy slows the progression of CKD, irrespective of the drug that is used. However, the use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs for this purpose has the added benefit of reducing proteinuria. Reduction in proteinuria also reduces the risk of progression.
  • Patients should be advised to limit their potassium intake by reducing foods with high potassium such as bananas. Potassium-binding resins such as patiromer can also be used.
  • Sodium bicarbonate supplementation may be indicated in patients who have chronic high-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Active vitamin D metabolites such as calcitriol should be given to patients with renal bone disease.
  • Hyperphosphatemia is treated with restriction of high phosphate foods such as milk and eggs, and with phosphate binders such as lanthanum and sevelamer.
  • Anemia associated with CKD is treated with darbepoetin after replenishing the iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12 stores of the body.

questions.text: An ultrasound was done on a pregnant Rh-negative patient  to screen for hydrops fetalis. What is the earliest sign that may be seen on USG?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of hydrops fetalis on a USG is scalp edema. Subcutaneous scalp edema is also known as the Halo sign. 

Other USG signs include:

  • Ascites
  • Pleural effusion 
  • Pericardial effusion 
  • Typical position termed as Buddha's position   

The image below shows skin thickening at the level of the fetal skull, on ultrasonography:

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for PID except______.
questions.solution:
Pregnancy is not a risk factor for PID. Instead, it plays a protective role in this condition.

The risk factors for developing PID are:

  • Unprotected sexual intercourse
  • Having multiple sex partners
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUD insertion
  • Early age of sexual intercourse (<18years)

The protective factors for PID are:

  • Pregnancy 
  • Using barrier contraception like condoms, diaphragms
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
  • Menopause

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding anaerobic glycolysis?

choices.text: Occurs in places like the eye lens and RBCs

questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase enzyme is needed in anaerobic glycolysis, not pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Under anaerobic conditions, pyruvate is reduced to lactate. This reaction is catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase.

Since RBC’s lack mitochondria, the further reactions of pyruvate in the TCA cycle cannot take place. Hence, glycolysis in erythrocytes always ends in the formation of lactate. Also, anaerobic glycolysis is the major fate for pyruvate in the lens and cornea of the eye, kidney medulla, leukocytes, because these are all poorly vascularized structures.

Net ATP produced per molecule of glucose under anaerobic conditions is 2. The NADH does not contribute to the ATP production because it gets used up in the reduction of pyruvate to lactate, which need NADH.

Related Pearl: Pyruvate metabolism

  Enzyme involved

Fate of pyruvate
1 Cahill cycle (Alanine aminotransferase)

Carries amino group from muscle to liver.

Converts alanine to pyruvate and vise-versa.
2 Pyruvate carboxylase Formation of oxaloacetate from pyruvate to be used in the TCA cycle
3 Pyruvate dehydrogenase Pyruvate to acetyl Co-A to be used in the TCA cycle
4 Lactic acid dehydrogenase Pyruvate to lactate(Anaerobic glycolysis)

questions.text: Which of the following complications is unlikely in a patient with gestational diabetes?
questions.solution:
Polyhydramnios is a complication of diabetes, not oligohydramnios.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is commonly defined as glucose intolerance first recognized during pregnancy.

Complications of gestational diabetes:

  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Preterm labor
  • Unexplained fetal demise
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Malformations
  • Altered fetal growth
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Polyhydramnios

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions, a dry tap may be seen on bone marrow aspiration?
questions.solution:
Acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AML M7) may yield a dry tap on marrow aspiration.

It may be associated with extensive bone marrow fibrosis as a result of the stimulation of the normal fibroblasts by the local secretion of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) by the leukemic cells.

questions.text: A man presents with rashes around the neck, as shown in the image below. Dietary history reveals that he has consumed jowar for a long duration. Which vitamin is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient with high intake of jowar and characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern rash is most likely suffering from pellagra. It is caused due to a deficiency of vitamin B3, known as niacin.

Pellagra, or niacin deficiency, presents with 3 classical Ds - dermatitis (photosensitive), diarrhea and dementia. Patients often have the Casal collar or Casal necklace. It is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4). If left untreated, pellagra leads to the 4th D of death. 

Jowar (sorghum) has high leucine content. This inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme responsible for the synthesis of niacin from amino acid tryptophan. Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can also cause pellagra due to their low levels of niacin and tryptophan.

questions.text: A dermatologist observes the following finding in a malnourished patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a magnified view of a burrowing trail of the scabies mite. The scaly patch on the left was caused by the scratching and it marks the mite's entry point into the skin. The mite has burrowed to the top-right, where it can be seen as a dark spot at the end. Burrow is the characteristic lesion of scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis.

The characteristic symptoms include intense itching and superficial burrows. In most people, the trails of the burrowing mites appear brownish linear or s-shaped tracks in the skin and occur as a result of excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis. These are found in the webspaces, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, back, breasts, buttocks, and external genitals.  

Larva currens and cutaneous larva migrans presents as pruritic erythematous papule at the site of penetration of the hookworms with an erythematous serpiginous larva track.

Pediculosis lesions present as erythematous papules with maculae cerulae.

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image represents "miliary tuberculosis". Individual lesions are small (2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma 

Miliary tuberculosis (TB) is the widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis via hematogenous spread. It occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. Miliary TB may infect any number of organs, including the lungs, liver and spleen.

The adjective “miliary” is derived from the resemblance of these foci to millet seeds. Montaux test is negative in miliary TB.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly involved vessel in patients with bleeding peptic ulcers on the posterior wall?
questions.solution: The most common vessel responsible for bleeding in peptic ulcer disease is the gastroduodenal artery. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, leading to hematemesis and melena.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following diseases develop features of androgen insensitivity?
questions.solution:
Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy results in androgen insensitivity. 

It is an X-linked lower motor neuron disorder caused by CAG repeats in the gene encoding the polyglutamine tracts of the androgen receptor. It presents with progressive weakness and wasting of limb and bulbar muscles and features of androgen insensitivity like gynecomastia and reduced fertility. 

Disease Pathological protein
Huntington's disease Huntington (Polyglutamine)
Spinocerebellar ataxia(SCA1, 2, 6, 7, 17 and DRPLA) Various proteins (Polyglutamine containing)
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis SOD1, TDP-43, FUS
Spinal-bulbar muscular atrophy Androgen receptor (Polyglutamine containing)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about endometriosis?

choices.text: In utero exposure to DES increases risk
Most common site is the cervix

questions.solution:
The most common site of occurrence of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of the ovary is known as endometrioma.

By definition, endometriosis is the occurrence of benign endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the cavity of the uterus. Endometriosis can occur anywhere in the body (except spleen) including the abdominal wall, lung, pleura, brain, etc.

It is a proliferative, hormone-dependent disease of the childbearing period. Women between the age groups of 30-40 years are most commonly affected. Risk factors for endometriosis are as follows:

  • Family history (7-10x risk with a 1st-degree relative)
  • Nulliparity
  • In utero exposure to Diethylstilbestrol (DES)
  • Estrogen dependent conditions/Estrogen therapy
  • Immunological factor - Impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestation presented with insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving her legs. Blood tests revealed a Hb value of 10.1 g/dl. Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator for her underlying condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, history suggestive of restless leg syndrome and Hb of 10.1g/dL points to a diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Serum ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of iron deficiency anemia in pregnant women.

This is because its concentrations are not affected by the recent intake of iron-rich foods. Serum ferritin concentration <15 μg/L indicates iron deficiency anemia.

However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls <30 μg/L, as this indicates early iron depletion.

Restless leg syndrome also called Willis-Ekbom Disease, causes unpleasant or uncomfortable sensations in the legs along with an irresistible urge to move them. It may be associated with iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: Which fascial layer should be dissected to separate the rectum from the coccyx while operating on a patient with rectal adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Waldeyer's fascia separates the rectum from the coccyx. 

The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following:

  • from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers’ fascia
  • from the coccyx and lower two sacral vertebrae- by Waldeyer’s fascia

Waldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses with the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retrorectal space into superior and inferior compartments. 

Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventing complications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Grawitz tumor?

choices.text: Derived from the proximal tubular epithelium
Clear cell is the most common histological type

questions.solution:
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) also known as Grawitz tumor or hypernephroma, is a radio-resistant tumor.

RCC accounts for 85% of renal neoplasms in adults. It is more common in males between the sixth to seventh decades. Clear-cell RCC is the most common type of renal cell cancer.

The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron is usually the site of origin of RCC.

Risk factors for RCC:

  • Smoking
  • Obesity
  • Family history of RCC
  • Drugs like phenacetin and diuretics
  • Thorotrast exposure

questions.text: Identify the area marked 'a' in the figure below.
questions.solution:
The image is of the floor of the 4th ventricle, and the area marked 'a' is the hypoglossal triangle.

The floor of the 4th ventricle is diamond-shaped and lies on the dorsal surface of the pons and superior half of the medulla. It is divided into two symmetrical halves by the longitudinal median sulcus. Each half is further divided by sulcus limitans into a medial region, medial eminence, and a lateral region, vestibular area.

The vestibular nuclei lie beneath the vestibular area.

At the superior end of the sulcus limitans, a bluish-gray area is produced by a cluster of nerve cells containing melanin pigment called substantia ferruginea/locus coeruleus.

At the inferior end of the medial eminence, the fibers from the motor nucleus of the facial nerve looping over the abducens nucleus are represented by the facial colliculus.

Inferiorly, the medial eminence is represented by the hypoglossal triangle overlying the hypoglossal nucleus and the vagal triangle overlying the dorsal nucleus of the vagus.

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The red line indicates an enzymatic reaction taking place in the presence of a competitive inhibitor.

The graph represents the enzymatic reaction velocity in relation to substrate concentration. The black line indicates the reaction taking place in the absence of any inhibitor.

In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the red line,

  • Vmax remains unchanged.
  • Km  is increased.

In the presence of a non-competitive inhibitor, as indicated by the blue line,

  • Vmax is decreased
  • Km remains unchanged

Note:

Suicide inhibitors are specialized substrate analogs. They contain a chemical group that can be transformed by the target enzyme. After binding to the active site of the enzyme, catalysis by the enzyme generates a highly reactive group that forms a covalent bond and blocks the function of the enzyme.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease is brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He has been neglecting symptoms of dizziness and palpitations for the past few days. His ECG is given below. The most possible diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of ventricular fibrillation. 

The features in the above ECG that support the diagnosis are:

  • Disordered electrical ventricular activation with no identifiable QRS complexes
  • No identifiable P-waves, no PR interval

Possible mechanisms of ventricular fibrillation include spiral wave reentry and multiple circulating reentry wavefronts.

The ECG features suggestive of ventricular tachycardia are as follows:

  • Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows in image below)
  • Absence of the P waves
  • Rate >100/min- in the ECG below, it is ~180 beats/min (1500/no. of small boxes between two R waves)

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Which finding is most likely to be seen in a patient with pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia.

During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia, renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. The hallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatinine levels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhanced tubular reabsorption.

The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system.

Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. This is often used as a predictive test.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a discrete thyroid swelling. USG reveals an isolated cystic swelling of the gland. Which of the following statements correctly expresses the risk of malignancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Isolated cystic swellings are malignant in 24% of males.

The general rule of thumb is that the risk of malignancy is greater in:

  • Isolated > dominant swellings
  • Solid > cystic
  • Men > women

The risk of malignancy in thyroid swellings, given by the rule of twelve, is depicted below. The risk of cancer in thyroid swelling can be expressed as a factor of 12.

questions.text: “Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in which phase of a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
“Proof of concept” for a new drug is generally proven in phase II of a clinical trial.

Phase II of clinical trials

  • It involves a small group of patients (50-500).
  • Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.
  • The study is designed to obtain "Proof of concept"(Potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

questions.text: Which of the following physiologic processes is not correctly matched?

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-B receptors decrease K+ conductance.
Presynaptic inhibition: GABA-A receptors increase Cl– conductance.

questions.solution:
GABA-B receptors are present in the spinal cord and appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via a G-protein that produces an increase in K+ conductance. 

PRE-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION

  • Presynaptic inhibition is a process mediated by neurons whose terminals are on excitatory endings, forming axoaxonal synapses.
  • The first transmitter shown to produce presynaptic inhibition was GABA. On the pre-synaptic membrane
    • Acting via GABA-A receptors, GABA increases Cl– conductance. 
    • GABA-B receptors appear to mediate presynaptic inhibition via a G-protein that produces an increase in K+ conductance. 
  • This leads to hyperpolarization of the pre-synaptic membrane and inhibition of release of the neurotransmittor from the pre-synaptic neuron.
 

POST-SYNAPTIC INHIBITION

  • Postsynaptic inhibition occurs when an inhibitory transmitter such as glycine or GABA is released from a presynaptic nerve terminal onto the postsynaptic neuron to induce an IPSP in the postsynaptic neuron.
  • In the figure shown below, an inhibitory transmitter such as GABA is released from the nerve terminals of an inhibitory interneuron (dark) that synapses on a postsynaptic neuron.

questions.text: A bone marrow examination is being planned for a patient with AL amyloidosis. Which of the following is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow examination in AL amyloidosis shows plasmacytosis.

The AL type of amyloid or primary amyloidosis is associated with immunocyte dyscrasias like multiple myeloma or other B cell neoplasms. The tumor cells in multiple myeloma secrete light chains of the immunoglobulins of either the lambda or kappa type, which get deposited in the tissues as amyloid.

The chemical nature of the amyloid is AL (A for amyloid and L for light chain).

questions.text: Which of the following factors are responsible for proper development of the pineal gland?
questions.solution:
• Home box transcription factor Pax6 and intermediate filament vimentin are required for proper development of pineal gland.
  • WT1 gene and the transcription factors SF-1 and DAX-1 regulate the development of adrenal gland.
  • The expression of transcription factors and growth factors play an important role in proper development of these glands. Dysregulation of expression of these factors leads to the development of congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency with symptoms of unstable angina. ECG done in pain-free interval showed biphasic T waves in precordial leads without ST changes. Cardiac troponins were normal. Coronary angiography revealed stenosis of the proximal left anterior descending artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Wellens syndrome. It is alternatively known as anterior, descending, T-wave syndrome. The ECG pattern of Wellens syndrome is relatively common in patients who exhibit symptoms consistent with unstable angina. 

ECG in the pain-free interval is characterized by deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in precordial leads and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated.

These patients are at high risk for impending large anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.

The ECG below shows biphasic T waves in leads V2 and V3 and inverted T waves in leads V4 and V5 in Wellens syndrome. 

Option A: Broken heart syndrome is another name for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Barlow syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse.

Option D: Brugada syndrome is a genetic cardiac rhythm disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries gives rise to helicine arteries of the penis?
questions.solution:
The deep artery of the penis (cavernosal artery) gives rise to helicine arteries of the penis. They open up into the sinusoidal space of the corpora cavernosa and supply it.

Blood supply of the penis:

  • The external pudendal artery supplies the skin of the penis.
  • The internal pudendal artery gives the following two branches:
    • Perineal artery - supplies the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and posterior scrotal surface.
    • Common penile artery - divides into the following three branches and supplies the shaft of the penis.
Branches of the common penile artery Structures supplied
Bulbourethral artery

Bulb of the penis

Corpus spongiosum with the urethra

Glans penis

Deep artery of the penis (cavernosal artery)

Corpora cavernosa
Dorsal artery of the penis

Glans penis

Corpus spongiosum (through the circumferential branches)

The below image shows a cross-section of the shaft of the penis and the arteries supplying them.

questions.text: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The Gomori methamine silver-stained smear of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. What is the most probable causative organism and the typical CD4+ count this infection occurs at?
questions.solution:
Cough, progressive dyspnea, bilateral interstitial infiltrates and the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stained smear showing black-colored cysts resembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and occurs at a CD4+ count <200/µl.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus causing pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. It has three morphological forms: trophozoite, pre-cyst and cyst. The infection is transmitted through respiratory droplets. Patients present with fever, non-productive cough and progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

It can be diagnosed by demonstration of the organism in broncho-alveolar lavage or lung biopsy specimens. PCR can also be done. Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients with AIDS.

The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:

Note: Toxoplasma gondii is an opportunistic infection causing encephalitis. On GMS staining of infected tissue, tachyzoites appear as crescent-shaped structures with blue cytoplasm and dark nucleus. Toxoplasmosis typically occurs in AIDS patients with a CD4+ count <100/µl. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 55-year-old female, who is a known case of sickle cell anemia, comes to the casualty with a history of severe eye pain, redness, and diminution of vision. On examination, the visual acuity is 6/60, and there is circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema, and a shallow anterior chamber. What is the drug of choice from the given options?
questions.solution:
This patient with complaints of severe headache, corneal congestion, and edema with a shallow anterior chamber most likely has acute angle closure glaucoma. Since this patient has a past history of sickle cell disease, intravenous mannitol is the drug of choice for this patient

Acetazolamide is contraindicated in cases of sickle-cell anemia since these drugs tend to increase sickling of erythrocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not present in the mitochondrial matrix?
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane, not mitochondrial matrix.

Note: In contrast to the other enzymes of citric acid cycle, succinate dehydrogenase is bound to the inner surface of inner mitochondrial membrane. Succinate dehydrogenase functions as complex II of electron transport chain.

questions.text: While examining a patient with upper motor neuron facial nerve palsy, you notice emotional expressions such as smiling and crying are unaffected. How will you explain this?

choices.text: Innervation by fibres from prefrontal cortex

questions.solution: The fibres from the thalamus are responsible for the involuntary movements of facial muscles in emotional states. These fibres reach the facial nerve nucleus via alternate pathways and are unaffected by UMN causes.

questions.text: A newborn baby has a characteristic rash as shown below. On examination, bilateral pearly white nuclear cataracts are noted, and a continuous murmur is auscultated. What family does the virus implicated in this syndrome belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of bilateral nuclear cataracts, blueberry muffin rash (image), and patent ductus arteriosus (continuous murmur) suggest congenital rubella syndrome. Rubella virus belongs to the family Matonaviridae.

Rubella virus, a pleomorphic enveloped ssRNA virus, previously belonged to the family Togaviridae. However, it has been recently changed to the family Matonaviridae by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV), making it the sole genus under the family Matonaviridae. 

Option A: Rhabdoviridae includes rabies virus.

Option B: Filoviridae includes Marburg virus and Ebola virus.

Option D: Calciviridae includes Norwalk agent.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: All of the following findings in a patient are suggestive of non-glomerular proteinuria except:

choices.text: Type of protein excreted is β2-microglobulin

questions.solution:
Non-glomerular proteinuria is characterized by the presence of N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG).

This form of proteinuria occurs as a result of tubular injury. N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG) is a lysosomal enzyme present in the proximal tubular cells and is released into the urine following any injury to the tubules.

Low-molecular-weight proteins such as β2-microglobulin are normally reabsorbed in the PCT. When there is tubular injury, the proportion of these proteins in urine increases. This lowers the albumin: β2-microglobulin ratio in urine.

In glomerular proteinuria, there is increased filtration of macromolecules like albumin across the glomerular capillary wall. NAG is absent as there is no tubular injury.

  Glomerular proteinuria Non-glomerular proteinuria

Type of protein excreted

 High molecular weight (Albumin) Low molecular weight (β2-microglobulin)

24 hr protein excretion

 > 1-2 g/day < 1 g/day 

RBC casts

 Present Absent

Albumin: β2 microglobulin ratio (Normal 100:1)

 1000:1 10:1

N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG)

 Absent Present

  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

questions.text: Your professor has assigned you to proofread a seminar on the anatomy of the conjunctiva made by a junior. In the explanation of conjunctival follicles, you spot a wrong statement that needs revision. What is that statement?

choices.text: Conjunctiva of new born does not produce follicles before 2-3 months of age.
Slit lamp may be necessary to differentiate between follicles and papillae.
Follicles are a hyperplasia of the normal vascular system.
Follicles are found in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva.

questions.solution:
Papillae (not follicles) are hyperplasia of the normal vascular system, with glomerulus-like branches of capillaries growing into the epithelium in inflammatory conditions. On the other hand, follicles are yellowish-white, round elevations of 1-2 mm diameter. Follicles are a localized aggregation of lymphocytes present in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva.

Image: Conjunctival papillae (hyperplastic epithelium and capillaries) shown in the first image followed by conjunctival giant follicles (round yellowish-white elevations)  shown in the second image.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the casualty with a 24-hour history of fever, sore throat, and diffuse erythematous macular rash. Past history is positive for unprotected intercourse with a new partner. What is true about the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute HIV syndrome. The virus is transmissible during this early infection period.

It is characterized by acute burst of viremia and wide virus dissemination and seeding of lymphoid organs (e.g., gut-associated lymphoid tissue), culminating in the destruction of CD4+ cells. 

The p24 antigen capture assay is used as a screening test for HIV infection in patients suspected of having the acute HIV syndrome.

Option A: The incubation period for acute HIV syndrome is around 3 to 6 weeks.

Option B: The acute HIV syndrome is typical of an acute viral syndrome and is very similar to acute infectious mononucleosis. The clinical findings include fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy. Rash, headache, arthralgia, and anorexia/weight loss can also be seen.

Option D: Opportunistic infections can occur during this stage of infection, reflecting the immunodeficiency that results from reduced numbers of CD4+T cells.

questions.text: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except
questions.solution:
Moderate ARDS is characterized by PaO2/FiO2: 101 - 200 mmHg. PaO2/FiO2: 200 - 300 mm/Hg is classified as mild ARDS. 

Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition:(requires each of the following criteria to be present to diagnose ARDS)

  • Onset - Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun < 1 week of a known clinical insult
  • Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
  • Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
  • Impairment of oxygenation: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS.

Severity

PaO2/FiO2

(On ventilator settings that include PEEP ≥5 cm H2O)

Mild

> 200 mmHg but ≤ 300 mmHg

Moderate

 > 100 mmHg but ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe ≤ 100 mmHg

Note: American-European Consensus Conference (AECC) classification of ARDS is no longer used.

questions.text: On which aspect of the humeral head is reverse Hill-Sachs lesion seen?
questions.solution:
The reverse Hill-Sachs lesion is seen on the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head.

It is also known as McLaughlin lesion. it refers to an impaction fracture of the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head.

It is seen following a posterior dislocation of the humerus. This occurs due to the impact of the glenoid rim on the humeral head.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters acts on the muscle, behind a bolus of food, in the process of peristalsis?
questions.solution:
Substance P and acetylcholine are released from neurons behind the bolus of food, causing smooth muscle contraction, which propels the food downwards.

NO and VIP are released by neurons in the anterograde direction from the bolus which produces relaxation in front of the stimulus.

questions.text:
Which of the following mode of inheritances is seen in Ehler–Danlos syndrome?
  1. Autosomal dominant
  2. Autosomal recessive
  3. Mitochondrial
  4. X-linked dominant
  5. Genomic imprinting
questions.solution:
The mode of inheritance of Ehler–Danlos syndrome (EDS) encompasses two Mendelian patterns, namely:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Autosomal recessive

The biosynthesis of collagen can be disturbed by genetic errors that may affect any one of the numerous structural collagen genes or enzymes necessary for posttranscriptional modifications of collagen. Such molecular heterogeneity results in the expression of EDS as a clinically variable disorder, with varied patterns of inheritance.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child weighing 13 kg brought with the complaints of vomiting and diarrhoea with dehydration for 2 days which was corrected with IV fluids. Now, the child looks hydrated but has poor feeding. How much fluid should the child receive?
questions.solution:
This child should recieve fluid at the rate of 46ml/hr.

Hourly Maintenance Water Rate:

  • For body weight 0 - 10 kg : 4 ml/kg/hr
  • For body weight 11 - 20 kg : 40 ml/hr(for first 10 kg) + 2 ml/kg/hr for each Kg beyond 10 Kg
  • For Body weight  >20 kg : 60 ml/hr(for first 20 kg) + 1 ml/kg/hr for each Kg beyond 20 Kg

So, for this child it is 40 ml/hr(for first 10 kg) + (2*3 ml/hr) = 46 ml/hr With total maintenance fluid per day being 1,150 ml.

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the following would you advise him to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has a low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon, candies, and syrupy foods.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about spasmodic dysphonia?

choices.text: May be associated with other dystonias
Abductor type produces breathy voice and adductor type produces strangulated voice
Botulinum toxin is used in treatment

questions.solution:
Spasmodic dysphonia is not only a local laryngeal disorder. It is associated with many neurological conditions too.

There are 2 types of spasmodic dysphonia:

Adductor dysphonia

  • The adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to go into adduction. The voice becomes strained/strangled. 
  • Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in the thyroarytenoid muscles on one or both sides to relieve the spasm.

Abductor dysphonia

  • It is due to the spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle and thus the glottis is kept open.
  • The patient gets a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice.

Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. Patients who do not respond to toxin injection can be treated by type 1 thyroplasty or fat injection.

questions.solution:
Capitate is the first carpal bone and pisiform is the last carpal bone to ossify.
