questions.text: The septum pellucidum extends between:
questions.solution:
Septum pellucidum extends between the corpus callosum and the fornix. 

The septum pellucidum is a membrane separating the anterior horns of the left and right lateral ventricles of the brain. It extends from the corpus callosum to the fornix.

It develops from the lamina terminalis. The part of the lamina terminalis that stretches between corpus callosum and fornix persists as septum pellucidum.

The image given below shows the septum pellucidum.

questions.text: During a colonoscopy on a 58-year-old female patient, a smooth nodular polyp is found and excised. The microscopic image is given. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the polyp.

choices.text: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years

questions.solution:
Hyperplastic polyps, as seen in the histological picture, do not have malignant potential.  

Elongated crypts, i.e., serrated (saw-toothed) or star-shaped appearance, is a characteristic feature of a hyperplastic polyp.

They are the most common type of colorectal polyps and are usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life. More than 90% occur in rectosigmoid region.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms form the citron bodies?
questions.solution:
Citron bodies are boat or leaf-shaped pleomorphic bacteria, usually associated with Clostridium septicum. 

It is a gram-positive, spore-forming, obligate anaerobic bacterium.

Gram stain morphology of Clostridium septicum from CSF (a) and blood culture (b) in 1000× magnification with spore formation(arrow) is shown below.

questions.text:
Match the following:

Disease

 Structural protein

1. Pemphigus vulgaris

a. Laminin

2. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

b. Desmoglein 1

3. Pemphigus foliaceus

 c. K5/K14

4. Junctional epidermolysis bullosa

 d. Desmoglein 3
questions.solution:
In pemphigus vulgaris, autoantibodies are directed towards desmoglein 3. Desmoglein 1 and desmocollins can also be involved. Desmoglein 3 is present predominantly in the mucosal epithelium. Thus, antibodies against it lead to severe mucosal blistering. Desmoglein 3 is also involved in pemphigus vegetans.

Patients with pemphigus foliaceus, who have anti-desmoglein 1 antibodies alone, exhibit skin blistering without mucosal involvement.

Epidermolysis bullosa simplex is associated with congenital defects in K5/K14 antigens.

Junctional epidermolysis bullosa is associated with congenital defects in laminin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with complaints of inability to conceive underwent the following investigation. Which of the following is false about the same?

choices.text: The best time to perform it is before ovulation
It is perfomed to detect uterine anomalies
It is the first-line investigation in genital tuberculosis
Premedication can be done with atropine

questions.solution:
The given image shows a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis.

Procedure of HSG:

  • It is best performed in the period between the last day of menses to ovulation, usually on the 9th/10th day of the cycle.
  • 10-15ml radioopaque dye is injected into the uterine cavity via Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter.
  • Fluoroscopy is performed as the dye passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. 
  • If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia into the peritoneum, and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used for the detection of:

  • Tubal block - It can be due to:
    • Strictures - fibrotic block
    • Inspissated amorphous material
    • Tubal spasm - This can occur in apprehensive patients. It is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.

Contraindications:

  • Genital tract infections, such as genital tuberculosis. This is due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Bleeding
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase:
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which toll-like receptors stimulate immune response against bacterial products?

choices.text: NFκB mediated transcription of nuclear factor

questions.solution:
Toll-like receptors (TLRs) stimulate immune response by NFκB mediated transcription of nuclear factors.

TLRs are pattern recognition receptors which activate two sets of transcription factors:

  • NF-κB - stimulates the synthesis and secretion of cytokines and the expression of adhesion molecules. Both are critical for the recruitment and activation of leukocytes
  • Interferon regulatory factors - stimulate the production of the antiviral cytokines like type I interferons

The image given below shows a toll-like receptor.

The various classes of innate immune receptors are as follows:

 Receptors Location Function
Toll-like receptors Plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles

Important TLRs and molecules recognised:

  • TLR2 - peptidoglycan of gram + bacteria, lipopolysaccharide of Leptospira
  • TLR3 - dsRNA viruses
  • TLR4Q - Chlamydia and lipopolysaccharide
NOD-like receptors Cytosol of immune cells and epithelial cells
  • Recognise substances from necrotic cells and microbial products
  • Signals via inflammasome which activates caspase and IL-1
C-type lectin receptors  Plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells
  • Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi
RIG-like receptors Cytosol of most cell types
  • Detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of infected cells
  • Stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines
  • Recognize short bacterial peptides containing N-formyl methionyl residues and stimulate chemotaxis
Mannose receptors Plasma membrane of macrophages, immature dendritic cells, and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells
  • Detect microbial sugars (which often contain terminal mannose residues) and induce phagocytosis of the microbes

Mannose receptor is a soluble pattern-recognition receptor. All the others are surface pattern-recognition receptors.

questions.text: What is the most commonly affected part in otosclerosis?
questions.solution: The most commonly affected part in the stapedial type of otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestrum lying in front of the oval window.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not true about necroptosis?

choices.text: It is a form of programmed cell death

questions.solution:
Caspase activation does not occur in necroptosis. It is a caspase-independent form of programmed cell death.

Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrosis (which is normally an unprogrammed process). Though the activation of this pathway is similar to apoptosis, there is no activation of caspases, which is an important part of apoptosis.

Necroptosis is triggered by the activation of TNFR1 by TNF-α. This induces the recruitment of RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and the formation of a necrosome. The necrosome reduces cellular ATP levels.

Necroptosis occurs in the following conditions:

  • Pathological - ischemic brain injury, neurodegenerative diseases, viral infections
  • Physiological - formation of the mammalian bone growth plate

The following table lists the differences between apoptosis and necroptosis:

Feature Apoptosis Necroptosis
Induction stimuli Oxidative stress, death receptor ligands, chemotherapy Viral or chemical exposure, radiation, endogenous or pathological factors
Morphological changes                   Nuclear pyknosis, membrane blebbing, generation of apoptotic bodies Swelling of cells and organelles, loss of membrane integrity
Molecular changes Cleavage of caspases, DNA fragmentation Acidosis, random DNA degradation, release of cellular proteins
Clearance Apoptotic bodies phagocytosed by neighboring cells and macrophages Necrotic cells ingested by macrophages, significant inflammation

questions.text: Mode of injury of a Cotton fracture ______
questions.solution:
Cotton fracture is due to abduction and external rotational injury.

The salient features about this fracture are:

  • It is also known as trimalleolar fracture.
  • It is a difficult and complex injury to treat. 
  • There is fracture of the medial, lateral, and posterior malleolus.
  • For plain X-ray 50° external rotation view is preferred.
  • It more often requires open reduction and internal fixation.

questions.text: While studying a community, the researcher found 30% of the population to be below 15 years of age, and 10% was over 65 years of age. What is the total dependency ratio of this population?
questions.solution:
The total dependency ratio in this population is 66.6%. 

This can be calculated as follows.

Here, the total population below 15 years of age is = 30%

Total population above 65 years of age = 10%

So, total population between 15-65 years of age = 100 - (30 + 10) = 60%

Hence, dependency ratio in this population = 100* (30% + 10%)/60% = 66.6%

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby was brought with severe diaper rash. The parents gave a history of recurrent infections in the past 4 months which required frequent hospitalization.  On examination white patches were present in oral mucosa which could be scraped easily. The biopsy of the thymus showed remnants of Hassall's corpuscles. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is due to defect only in cell mediated immune response
B cell count can be normal

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). The biopsy of the thymus showing remnants of Hassall's corpuscles indicates it is due to adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency. SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Usually the defect lies in the T-cell compartment with secondary impairment in humoral immunity.

Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

There are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance:

1. X-linked SCID is the most common form and hence it is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect is the mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. T-cell numbers are greatly reduced, and although B cells may be normal in number, antibody synthesis is impaired because of the lack of T-cell help. The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

2. Autosomal recessive is most commonly caused due to deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA). The deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes.

In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells. In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

Note: X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Which of the following findings are you unlikely to see in a patient with achondroplasia?
questions.solution:
Squaring of the iliac blades and not the acetabula give a tombstone appearance in achondroplasia.

Other radiological findings seen in achondroplasia include:

  • Large skull with -
    • Prominent forehead
    • Depressed nasal bridge
    • Small foramen magnum that is funnel-shaped
  • The epiphyses have V-shaped distal ends with deep intercondylar notches—the ‘chevron’ sign
  • Bullet nose vertebrae with posterior scalloping
  • Trident hand (as shown below)

questions.text: Which of the following is a natural ligand for CXCR4?
questions.solution:
SDF-1 is the natural ligand for CXCR4, which blocks the entry of HIV into the cell. 

The natural chemokine ligands for the major HIV co-receptors can block entry of HIV by binding to CCR5 or CXCR4 and prevent HIV binding. There are different chemokine ligands for CCR5 and CXCR4:  

  • CCR5: CC-chemokines RANTES (CCL5), MIP-1α (CCL3), MIP-1β (CCL4)
  • CXCR4: SDF-1

 

Good to know:

  • Strains of HIV that utilize CCR5 as a co-receptor are referred to as R5 viruses.
  • Strains of HIV that utilize CXCR4 are referred to as X4 viruses.
  • Viral strains that are dual tropic utilize both CCR5 and CXCR4 and are referred to as R5X4 viruses.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent inhaled anesthetic?
questions.solution:
The most potent inhaled anesthetic among the given options is halothane, with a minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) value of 0.75%.

The least potent inhaled anesthetic is nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104%.

Note: Methoxyflurane has a MAC of 0.16%, making it more potent than halothane. However, it is obsolete now. The most potent agent overall is methoxyflurane and the most potent agent in clinical use is halothane.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: You have just performed defibrillation in a patient with ventricular fibrillation. According to the ACLS guidelines, what should be your next step?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions should be resumed immediately following shock delivery.

Pulse check and reanalysis of the cardiac rhythm is performed only after 2 minutes of chest compression and rescue breaths. This is because the heart is temporarily stunned by a defibrillator shock and so chest compressions would benefit the patient by providing coronary blood flow during this period.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm or asystole for at least 5 seconds. It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate immediately because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

If after 2 minutes, the rhythm remains the same, then another shock is delivered. Chest compression and rescue breaths are resumed and 1 mg epinephrine is administered. Consideration is given for an advanced airway placement.

If after 2 minutes the rhythm still remains the same, the first dose of amiodarone 300mg bolus is given.

With the next cycle of CPR, a shock is delivered and 1 mg of epinephrine is given. And with the cycle of CPR after that, shock is delivered and the second dose of amiodarone- 150mg is given

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampatti class of this patient.
questions.solution:
The image shows Mallampatti class II airway.

The modified Mallampatti classification is used in the assessment of airway. It is a predictor of the difficulty of intubation or difficult airway.

The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without saying "ahh."

Modified Mallampati classification:

  • Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis. 
  • Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible.
  • Class II: Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible.
  • Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible.
  • Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all. Only hard palate visible.

Classes 3 and 4 are difficult intubation situations.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added. 

Seshagiri Rao Mallampati (1941 – ) is an Indian-origin American anesthesiologist. The ‘original’ Mallampati scoring system had only three stages and was published in 1985.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, and white-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid).

Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and is more common in obese females(hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the most common symptom is menorrhagia.

Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations:

Sub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the most common type of uterine fibroids.

Other options:

Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or as a diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and may show areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, they appear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into the uterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal endometrium.

Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky and symmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may show tiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy. Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women.

The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis:

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is required for the only energy-requiring step of fatty acid oxidation?
questions.solution:
The only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation is catalyzed by the thiokinase enzyme.

In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase or thiokinase catalyses the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acid for oxidation.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in Fatty acid Transfer Across Mitochondrial membrane

Enzyme

Site of action

Action

Acyl-CoA synthetase (Thiokinase)

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Converts free fatty acid into Acyl CoA

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Transfers long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine.

Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Along with carnitine palmitoyl transferase I oxidizes long-chain fatty acids in the mitochondria.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for a patient with suspected Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
CSOM is a middle ear disease with symptoms of ear discharge and is not a differential for Ménière’s.

Ménière’s is a cochlear pathology with symptoms of vertigo, hearing loss & tinnitus.

Differentials of Ménière’s disease:

  • Vestibular neuronitis
  • BPPV
  • Cervical spondylosis
  • Acoustic tumours
  • Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
  • Labyrinthitis
  • Perilymph fistula
  • Migraine induced vertigo

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of pain in the left knee, which is tender on palpation. X-ray shows a 5 cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis, with a soap bubble appearance. Microscopy is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoclastoma/ giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone.

GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL. It promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.

GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis. The majority arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal extremities. The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue.

Histopathologically, sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells are seen with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.

The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in osteoclastoma.

Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally.

Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are rarely fatal. The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in GCT.

 Note: The E mnemonic for GCT:

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Egg-shell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: The given incidental finding in the ileum was noted while performing an appendectomy for a child. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Gastric mucosa is the most common heterotropic mucosa seen
Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in children

questions.solution:
The above finding depicts Meckel's diverticulum. Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in adults with Meckel’s diverticula. Bleeding is the most common manifestation in children.

Meckel's diverticulum has a 2:1 male-to-female preponderance and is the most common congenital anomaly of the small intestine. It is situated on the antimesenteric border of the ileum, usually 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve, and occurs due to incomplete closure of the vitelline duct. It is a true diverticulum consisting of all layers. 

It can present as:

  • Incidental findings during surgery
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the form of hemorrhage in children
  • Intestinal obstruction in the form of volvulus, intussusception (urge to defecate, vomiting, red current stools) 
  • Diverticulitis (right lower quadrant pain)

In children, 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in Meckel's diverticulum and is the most accurate diagnostic modality. However, in adults, less ectopic gastric tissue is seen, so the test is not very accurate. The sensitivity and specificity can be improved by the use of cimetidine.

In case of false-negative results, barium studies, mesenteric arteriography, or double-balloon endoscopy can be used for diagnosis.

Treatment is diverticulectomy or segmental resection of ileum containing diverticulum. In children, an incidentally found asymptomatic diverticulum has to be resected. 

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
questions.solution:
The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis.

It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.

questions.text: ANA pattern specific to SLE is?
questions.solution:
RIM pattern staining of ANA is found to be highly specific for SLE.

Anti-dsDNA and anti-Sm antibodies are highly specific for SLE, but anti-Sm antibodies lack sensitivity. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Sm antibodies are seen in approximately 70 and 30 percent of patients with SLE, respectively. Hence, rim pattern is a better answer than the speckled pattern.

  • RIM pattern - SLE (probably anti dsDNA)
  • Homogenous pattern - drug-induced SLE (probably anti-histone)
  • Speckled pattern – found in all connective tissue disorder
  • Nucleolar pattern – scleroderma
  • Centromere pattern - CREST 

 

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is a third generation BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Ponatinib is a third-generation BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor.

Classification of BCR-ABL kinase inhibitors: 

  • First-generation: most likely to develop resitance.
    • Imatinib 
  • Second-generation: active against imatinib-resistant CML cases but not against T315I mutant cases. 
    • Nilotinib
    • Dasatinib 
    • Bosutinib 
  • Third-generation: active against T315I mutant CML cases and other known mutant cases. 
    • Ponatinib

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the resting membrane potential (RMP) in a nerve fibre?

choices.text: It is equal to the RMP of inner hair cells of cochlea
It can be measured by surface electrodes
It becomes more positive as extracellular K+ increases
It depends on the equilibrium potential of Na+

questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential is close to the equilibrium potential for K+. So, changes in the external concentration of this ion can have major effects on the resting membrane potential.

  • If the extracellular level of K+ is increased (hyperkalemia), the resting potential moves closer to the threshold for eliciting an action potential, thus the neuron becomes more excitable.
  • If the extracellular level of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), the membrane potential is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

Option a: The RMP of a nerve fiber is -70 mV, while the RMP of inner hair cells is between -45 and -60 mV relative to the fluid that bathes the basal end of the cell.

Option b: The membrane potential can be measured only when one electrode is inserted into the interior of the cell.

Option d: It depends on the equilibrium potential of K+.

questions.text: During postmortem examination of the skull of a person who committed suicide on a railway track, the following finding is noted. What is the inference?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple fracture lines dividing the skull into fragments. Hence, it is a mosaic fracture/ spider-web fracture of the skull.

It is a comminuted depressed fracture that also has fissures radiating from it, forming a spider’s-web or mosaic pattern. These fractures are formed due to a significant force striking over a broad area.

The below image shows a spider-web fracture of the skull.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: An elderly woman with hypothyroidism presents to the ER with decreased consciousness, hypothermia, sinus bradycardia, and hypotension. Her family members reveal that she has not been taking her thyroid medications recently. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels and reduced T3 and T4 levels. All of the following can be used in the treatment except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of myxedema coma. Hypotonic IV fluids are avoided in the course of treatment of this condition. However, hypertonic saline is used.

Hypotonic fluids may exacerbate water retention and dilutional hyponatremia secondary to impaired renal perfusion and inappropriate vasopressin.

Treatment of myxedema coma includes:

  • Levothyroxine (T4) can be administered as a single IV bolus of 500 μg. Although further doses are strictly not required, it is continued at 50-100 μg/day.
  • An alternative mode of treatment is the IV administration of liothyronine (T3) or via NG tubes with doses ranging from 10-25 μg every 8-12 hours in case T4 to T3 conversion in myxedema is impaired.
  • Parenteral hydrocortisone should be administered to treat a condition of impaired adrenal reserve in profound hypothyroidism.
  • Hypertonic saline or IV glucose may be recommended for treatment.
  • External warming is indicated only if the temperature is less than 30oC.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Doyen’s mouth gag is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on the molar teeth.

Option A: Doyen’s retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall in abdominal and pelvic surgeries to expose the field of operation.

Option C: Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp is used for resection and anastomosis of the intestine in cases of:

  • Strangulated hernia
  • Accidental injuries to the gut
  • Intestinal growths
  • Gastric/intestinal bypass surgeries.

Option D: Joll’s thyroid retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in thyroid surgeries to retract skin.

questions.text: A new test for hepatitis C is performed on 200 patients with the biopsy-proven disease and 200 patients who are free of the disease. The test shows positive results on 180 of the patients with the disease and negative results on 150 of the patients without the disease. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
The specificity of the above screening test is 75%.

The given data is represented below:

 

Hep C +

Hep C -

Total

Test +

180(TP)

50(FP)

230

Test -

20(FN)

150(TN)

170

Total

200(TP+FN)

200(FP+TN)

400

TP- true positive, FP- false positive, FN- false negative, TN- true negative

Specificity = TN/(FP + TN) x 100 = 150/200 = 75%

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 180/200 = 90%

PPV= TP/(TP + FP) x 100 = 180/230 = 78%

NPV=TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 150/170 = 88%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: What test is being performed in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The test depicted in the given image is diascopy.

It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic onto the skin to cause blanching by compressing blood out of small vessels. This allows other colors to be evaluated.

Some uses of diascopy are as follows: 

  • Apple jelly nodules -  Yellow-brown lesions seen in lupus vulgaris and sarcoidosis.
  • Spider naevi - Compression of radiating arterioles is noted. 
  • Differentiation of erythema (disappears) and purpura (remains unaltered).

The image given below shows apple-jelly nodules on diascopy.

questions.text: Which of the following dopamine receptor agonists has antioxidant properties?
questions.solution:
Pramipexole is a dopamine receptor agonist that has an additional antioxidant effect. 

Pramipexole has a possible neuroprotective effect by its ability to scavenge hydrogen peroxide and enhance neurotrophic activity.

questions.text: You are an anaesthesia resident posted in the pediatrics OT. A spontaneously breathing 6 year old child is set to undergo a minor elective procedure. Which of the following circuits would be the best choice for ventilating this patient?
questions.solution:
Jackson Rees modification of Ayre's T piece is the circuit of choice for ventilating a spontaneously breathing child during anesthesia.

Jackson Rees modification of Ayre's T piece is classified as a Mapleson's F system, although it was not included in the original description by Prof Mapleson.

It is used in children <6 years or <20 kgs.

Mapleson Circuit Comments
Type A (Magill's circuit)

Circuit of choice for spontaneous ventilation
Type B

Obsolete

Type C (Water's to and fro)

Obsolete
Type D (Bain's circuit)

Circuit of choice for controlled ventilation. Most commonly used circuit.
Type E (Ayre's T piece)

Circuit of 2nd choice in children
Type F (Jackson Rees Modification) Circuit of choice in children (<20 kg)

Jackson Rees modification of Ayre's T piece. 

FGI - Fresh gas inlet; RB - Reservoir bag; P - Patient

questions.text: Pasturization is done at ______.
questions.solution:
Pasteurization of milk is done by the following methods:  

  • Holder method: Heat at 63°C for 30 minutes
  • Flash process: Heat at 72°C for 15–20 seconds

Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings is first to appear in a patient suspected of acute myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
During acute myocardial infarction, the ECG evolves through 3 stages:

  1. T-wave peaking and T-wave inversion: 
    • Peaked T-wave aka hyperacute T-wave- first ECG change (occurs within minutes)
    • If the blood flow is restored or the oxygen demands of the heart are met, the T waves will revert to normal
    • If myocardial cell death has occurred, T wave inversions appear (over days) and persist for months to years.
    • A nonspecific finding and is indicative only of ischemia and not diagnostic of infarction
  2. ST-segment elevation occurs over minutes to hours (after T-wave peaking)
  3. The appearance of new pathologic Q-waves:
    • Occurs over hours to days (after ST-segment elevation) and is indicative of an evolving MI
    • The persistence of pathological Q-waves indicates irreversible myocardial cell death

questions.text: Which of the following Cholera  vaccines is no longer produced?
questions.solution:
The live attenuated single-dose vaccine CVD103-HgR is no longer produced. 

The three types of oral cholera vaccines available are:

  • Dukoral- monovalent vaccine based on formalin and heat killed whole cells of V.cholerae O1 with the recombinant cholera toxin B unit. It comes with a bicarbonate buffer.
  • Sanchol and mORCVAX
  • Euvichol

questions.text: In a population of 10000, the prevalence of a disease is 20%. The sensitivity of a screening test is 95% and specificity is 80%. What is the positive predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value (PPV) of the test is 54.3%.

The prevalence of the disease is 20% in 10000, i.e., 2000 people have the disease(TP + FN) and 8000 are disease-free (FP + TN).

The sensitivity of the test is 95%, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 95%.

Thus, the true positives (TP)= 95/100 x (TP + FN) = 95/100 x 2000 = 1900.

The specificity of the test is 80%, i.e. TN/(FP + TN) = 80%.

Thus, the true negatives (TN)= 80/100 x (FP + TN) = 80/100 x 8000 = 6400.

The given data is represented below:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

1900(TP)

1600(FP)

3500(TP+FP)

Test -

100(FN)

6400(TN)

6500(FN+TN)

Total

2000(TP+FN)

8000(FP+TN)

10000

TP- true positive, FP- false positive, FN- false negative, TN- true negative

From the above table, PPV is calculated as TP/(TP + FP) x 100 = 1900/3500 = 54.3%.

An alternate formula(Bayes theorem) that can be used is PPV = (Sn x P) / (Sn x P)+[(1-Sp)(1-P)]

Sn- Sensitivity, P- Prevalence, Sp- Specificity

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to dystrophin-glycoprotein complex?
questions.solution:
Perlecan is a large extracellular matrix proteoglycan that plays a crucial role in tissue development and organogenesis.

Dystrophin-glycoprotein complex

  • The dystrophin-glycoprotein complex provides a structural link between the cytoskeleton of the muscle cell and the extracellular matrix, which appears to stabilize the sarcolemma, adds strength to the muscle by providing a scaffolding for the fibrils and prevents contraction-induced injury (rupture).
  • Organisation of DG complex
    • Dystrophin connects F-actin to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan via smaller proteins called Syntrophins.  
    • This β-dystroglycan, in turn connects to the merosin subunit of laminin 211 in the extracellular matrix via α-dystroglycan. 
    • The dystroglycans are also associated with a complex of four transmembrane glycoproteins, α-, β-, γ-, and δ-sarcoglycan and sarcospan.

 

APPLIED ASPECT

  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
    • X-linked recessive disorder
    • Deletion of DMD gene which codes for Dystrophin
  • Becker muscular Dystrophy
    • Dystrophin is present but altered or reduced in amount
  • Limb Girdle Dystrophy
    • Sarcoglycan is mutated

questions.text: Which of the following is false?

choices.text: Cofactors have functions similar to those of prosthetic groups.
Cofactors bind in a transient, dissociable manner to enzymes.
The most common cofactors are metal ions.
Enzymes that use metal ion as a cofactor are termed as metalloenzymes.

questions.solution:
Enzymes that use metal-ion as a cofactor are termed as metal-activated enzymes (and not metalloenzymes).

Metalloenzymes are prosthetic groups in which the metal is tightly and irreversibly bound to the enzyme. The metal forms an integral part of its active structure. Metal-activated enzymes are those that have a cofactor containing metal (inorganic) which are loosely and reversibly bound to the enzyme. They show enhanced activity in the addition of metal.

A cofactor is a non-protein part of a holoenzyme that can be separated part from the protein part. Cofactors are mostly metal ions or inorganic. If an organic compound is present in a cofactor, it is called a coenzyme. Cofactors serve functions similar to those of prosthetic groups. Cofactors bind in a transient, dissociable manner to enzymes. Cofactors must be present in the medium surrounding the enzyme for catalysis to occur.

questions.text: What is the ligament of Weigert?

choices.text: Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens
Attachment of the lens to the ciliary muscles

questions.solution:
The hyaloideo-capsular ligament of Weigert is the attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens. 

It is the annular region (1–2 mm in width and 8–9 mm in diameter) where the vitreous is attached to the posterior aspect of the lens.

Erggelet’s or Berger’s space is at the centre of the hyaloideo-capsular ligament, a potential space between the vitreous and the lens. The canal of Cloquet arises from this space and courses posteriorly through the central vitreous, which is the former site of the hyaloid artery in the embryonic vitreous.

Posteriorly, Cloquet’s canal opens into a funnel-shaped region anterior to the optic disc, whch is known as the area of Martegiani.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of OCPs?
questions.solution:
Thyroid disorders like hypothyroidism are not a contraindication for OCP usage.

Contraindications of OCPs:

  • Absolute contraindications -
    • Breast and genital cancers
    • Liver disease
    • History of thromboembolism
    • Cardiac abnormalities
    • Congenital hyperlipidemia
    • Undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Relative contraindications - 
    • Age over 40 years, if smoker >35 years
    • Mild hypertension
    • Chronic renal disease
    • Epilepsy
    • Migraine
    • First 6 months of breastfeeding
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Gallbladder disease
    • History of infrequent bleeding or amenorrhea

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the therapeutic modality shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows photochemotherapy (PUVA therapy), used for the treatment of vitiligo. It causes suppression of T lymphocyte action.

The UVA spectrum is 320-400 nm. When it is used in combination with an oral or topical psoralen photosensitizer, it is known as PUVA therapy. The most frequently-used oral psoralens are 8‐methoxy psoralen (8‐MOP) and 5‐methoxy psoralen (5‐MOP).

The mechanisms of action of PUVA:

  • Inhibition of DNA replication - DNA cross‐linking by psoralen photoadducts
  • Langerhans cell depletion
  • Immunosuppressive effects on T‐lymphocyte function
  • Stimulation of melanogenesis
  • Migration and the restoration of Th17/regulatory T-cell imbalance in psoriasis

Indications of PUVA therapy:

  • Psoriasis
  • Atopic eczema
  • Vitiligo
  • Polymorphic light eruption
  • Cutaneous T cell lymphoma

The UVB part of the spectrum is 280-320 nm. Lamps utilizing the 311-313 nm frequencies are called narrow‐band UV (NBUVB). UVB phototherapy has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties. 

Vitiligo may respond both to NB‐UVB and PUVA. NBUVB is more effective than PUVA but the response is variable and treatment usually has to be prolonged, often over many months to a year or more.

questions.text: A patient operated for direct inguinal hernia developed sensory loss at the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.

The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in direct inguinal hernia. Iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.

Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: How does myosin change during muscle hypertrophy?

choices.text: From α-heavy chain to β-heavy chain
From β-heavy chain to α-heavy chain
From β-light chain to α-light chain
From α-light chain to β-light chain

questions.solution:
During muscle hypertrophy, the α-isoform of the myosin heavy chain is replaced by the β-isoform. It produces slower and more energetically economic contraction.

During hypertrophy, there may occur a switch of contractile proteins from the adult isoforms to the fetal or infantile isoforms.

questions.text: Histopathological findings of a lung tumor biopsy are shown below. Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific marker of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given image shows keratin pearls and islands of large polygonal malignant cells. These as seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the lungs. P40 is the most sensitive and specific marker for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lungs.

Other markers include cytokeratin 5/6 and P63.

TTF-1 and napsin-A are the markers for adenocarcinoma.

Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

Note: The 2015 World Health Organization Classification of Lung Tumors has made a recommendation that at least one antibody each for squamous (P40 or P63) and glandular (e.g. TTF-1) differentiation should be used for an initial workup. Thus a simple panel of TTF-1 and p40 may be able to classify most non-small cell carcinoma-not otherwise specified cases.

questions.text: You are tasked with conducting a health and wellness survey of the employees of your hospital. Which of the following scales will you not use to classify their socio-economic statuses?
questions.solution:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Scales that have been used for SES are:

  • Udai Pareek scale
  • Kuppuswamy scale
  • Radhukar scale
  • Jalota scale
  • Shirvastava scale
  • Bharadwaj scale
  • Kulshestra scale
  • Hollingshead scale.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: Elevated levels of which of the following is not a predictor for stroke?
questions.solution:
Elevated plasminogen levels are not associated with stroke. Elevated levels of the following are predictors for stroke: 

  • C-reactive protein - also indicates risk for MI, PAD and used to monitor effectiveness of risk reduction measures like exercise, weight loss
  • Homocysteine - also correlates with MI, PAD, venous thrombosis, and premature vascular disease
  • Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 - marker of hemostatic and/or fibrinolytic function and also predicts risk of MI

questions.text: Which chromosome contains the major susceptible gene for type 1 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
The major susceptibility gene for type 1 diabetes mellitus is located in the HLA region of chromosome 6.

Type I diabetes mellitus occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and is usually triggered by infections. The HLA complex is most commonly involved. The common HLA associations include:

  • Causative - HLA-DQA1*0501 and DQB*0201
  • Protective - HLA-DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DRB1*1501

Other genomic associations of type I diabetes mellitus include the CTLA-4 gene and IL-2 receptor.

Type 2 diabetes mellitus is associated with mutations in the calpain-10 gene on chromosome 2. It results in insulin resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not synthesized by pre-core mutants of hepatitis B virus?
questions.solution:
Pre-core mutants of hepatitis B virus are unable to synthesize HBeAg.

In the HBV genome, the C gene consists of 2 regions:

  • Pre-C region- When translation begins from the Pre-C region, HBeAg is synthesized.
  • C-region- When it begins from the C-region, HBcAg is synthesized.

In the HBeAg sequence of pre-core mutants, there is a G to A switch at the 28th amino acid, causing a stop codon. Hence, pre-core mutants are unable to synthesize HBeAg.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought with complaints of bedwetting at night. There is no history of bedwetting during day time. His urine examination was normal. Specific gravity was 1.020. What would be your advice?
questions.solution:
According to the given history, the child had nocturnal enuresis with normal findings on urine examination and hence consulting a child psychologist is the most appropriate option.

Nocturnal enuresis:

  • It refers to the occurrence of involuntary voiding at night after 5 years of age.
  • If no daytime symptoms and physical and urine examination are normal, then further evaluation for urinary tract pathology is not warranted.
  • An USG is done in an older child (usually >7 years) with enuresis or in those who do not respond to therapy.
  • Active treatment should be avoided in children younger than 6 years of age.
  • Psychological therapy includes motivational therapy (star charts), Conditioning therapy (auditory or vibratory alarms) and self-hypnosis. It helps the child to deal with enuresis psychologically and motivate the child to void at night if he wakes up with a full bladder.
  • Pharmacological therapy ( imipramine and desmopressin) is intended to treat the symptoms of enuresis and thus is regarded as second line and is not curative. Desmopressin tablet with a dosage of 0.2-0.6 mg at bed time can be given.

questions.text: What is not true regarding a Bochdalek hernia?

choices.text: Early respiratory distress leading to early diagnosis and treatment is a good prognostic sign
The contents of hernial sac commonly includes retroperitoneal fat, left kidney or spleen
The condition is diagnosed prenatally by ultrasonography.
Pericardial cyst is a differential diagnosis.

questions.solution:
Early respiratory distress, within 6 hours of birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.

Features of a Bochdalek hernia:

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Ultrasonography findings:

  • Polyhydramnios
  • Chest mass
  • Mediastinal shift
  • Gastric bubble or a liver in the thoracic cavity
  • Fetal hydrops

Differential diagnosis:

  • Eventration
  • Cystic lung lesion (pulmonary sequestration or cystic adenomatoid Malformation)
  • Group B streptococcal sepsis: associated with delayed onset of symptoms and a CDH often on the right side.
  • Pneumothorax: always occurs on contralateral to the side of CDH.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair

The viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fio2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: If the tidal volume is 500 mL, PeCO2 is 30 mmHg and PaCO2 is 45 mmHg, calculate the dead space?
questions.solution:
The Bohr-enghoff equation is used to calculate physiological dead space/total dead space.

The original Bohr equation required measurement of the alveolar partial pressure of CO2 (PACO2).

Later Enghoff modified the equation and replaced the PACO2 with PaCO2 (partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood). Enghoff's modification of Bohr equation is:

Where,

  • VD is the physiological dead space
  • VT is the tidal volume
  • PaCO2 is the partial pressure of CO2 in the arterial blood
  • PeCO2 is the average partial pressure of CO2 in the entire expired air.  

Substituting the values:

Vd=(45-30/45) x 500=166.66 ml

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male is concerned about his risk of developing coronary heart disease. What cholesterol/HDL ratio would you aim to achieve in this patient?
questions.solution: A cholesterol/HDL ratio <3.5 is recommended for the prevention of coronary heart disease (CHD).

questions.text: If identified and intervened early, rapid clinical improvement can be expected in a patient with which of the following causes of dementia ?
questions.solution:
If diagnosed and intervened early, clinical improvement can be expected with normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), as it is a reversible cause of dementia.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus can present with the following triad (Adam’s triad or Hakim's triad), remembered as:

  1. Urinary incontinence (wet)
  2. Dementia (wacky)
  3. Gait disturbance (wobbly)           

Causes of dementia:

Reversible Irreversible
  • Intracranial tumors
  • Subdural hematoma
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Autoimmune encephalopathy
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Meningitis 
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lewy body disease
  • Vascular dementia
  • Creutzfeld-Jacob disease
  • Pick's disease

questions.text: Which infection causes more damage to the mucosa and the wall of the tube leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, chlamydial infection causes the most amount of damage to the mucosa and the wall of the fallopian tubes leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage.

Chlamydial infection can remain asymptomatic in the endo-cervix. Hence, the infection goes unnoticed and untreated. Thus, it can lead to more damage and complications.

Gonococcal infection is more symptomatic than chlamydial infection. Hence, it is diagnosed early and causes less damage to the tubes than chlamydial infection.

Mycoplasma and Mobiluncus generally cause lower genital tract infections like cervicitis and vaginitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an integrin molecule?
questions.solution:
CD 31 or platelet endothelial cell-adhesion molecule 1 (PECAM-1) is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily. It is not an integrin molecule.

The various endothelial and leukocyte adhesion molecules include:

  • Selectin family - mediates initial rolling interactions between leukocytes and endothelium
  • Integrin family - 
    • Involved in migration and firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium
    • Includes LFA-1, MAC-1, and VLA-4
  • Immunoglobulin family -
    • PECAM (CD31) - most important adhesion molecule for diapedesis
    • ICAM-1 - binds to β2 integrins on leukocytes

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the left lung in the above condition points to a diagnosis of left-sided pneumothorax. 

Marfan's syndrome is one of the causes for seconday spontaneous pneumothorax in adults. 

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air in the pleural space. 

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to adjacent lung 
  • Complete lung collapse, as well as subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum, may be seen
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph)

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine position(common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the non-dependent portions of the pleural space, abnormally deepening the costophrenic angle. This sign is indicative of pneumothorax in such patients and may be the only visible clue, especially when patient can not be imaged upright.

The image below is plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax with deep sulcus sign (shown by arrow):

When there is a progressive accumulation of air intrapleurally in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration), it is called Tension pneumothorax. It can result in compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis?
questions.solution:
The pathognomonic sign of acute anterior uveitis is keratic precipitates (KP).

Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits at the back of cornea. The composition of KPs varies with the type of uveitis. 

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:

  1. Corneal signs
    • Corneal edema
    • Keratic precipitates (Pathognomonic)
    • Posterior corneal opacity
  2. Anterior chamber signs
    • Aqueous cells
    • Aqueous flare (earliest sign)
    • Hypopyon
    • Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae
  3. Iris signs
    • Loss of normal pattern
    • Change in color 
    • Iris nodules (Koeppe, Busacca)
    • Posterior synechiae
    • Neovascularization
  4. Pupillary signs
    • Constricted pupil
    • Irregular pupil shape
    • Ectropion of pupillary margin
    • Occlusion pupillae

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with the following skin lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows typical erythematous papules and nodules along with few whiteheads, suggestive of acne vulgaris.

Other options:

Option B: Acne rosacea is a disorder that appears mainly in people within 30 to 50 years of age. The lesions are mainly present on the convexities of the face but don't lead to central crusting or scarring. It is followed by triggering factors such as sunlight exposure, emotional disturbances, spicy food, alcohol, etc.,

Given below is an image showing acne rosacea:

Option C: Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition which presents with erythematous patches with superficial scaling, affecting areas with a high density of sebaceous glands- scalp, face, central chest, and anogenital areas.

Option D: Milia are small cysts formed around the pilosebaceous follicles usually seen over nose, cheek, forehead of neonates. Pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts. Resolve spontaneously without scarring.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

  • Rosacea

  • Infantile hemangioma

questions.text: Halban's disease is ______

choices.text: Irregular shedding  due to persistent corpus luteum

questions.solution:
• Halbans disease is irregular shedding due to persistent corpus luteum.
  • It is rare and usually self-limiting. 
  • Menstruation occurs on time and is prolonged but not heavy.

questions.text: A skin transplant was done from a sister to her brother. After a few years, a brother-to-sister skin transplant was done, but rejection occurred. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes an Eichwald-Silmser effect, which is a unilateral sex-linked histo-incompatibility.

While transplants between same-sex siblings are successful, grafts from female to male are also successful, but an exception is seen when the donor is a male and the recipient is a female. Such grafts are rejected as the grafted male tissue (XY) will have antigens determined by the Y chromosome which will be absent in the female (XX) recipient.

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CT pulmonary angiography should be performed as it is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).

Option A: Most patients with acute PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation-perfusion scan can be done. 

The images below demonstrate a pulmonary embolus (marked by arrows). The image of the gross specimen shows saddle thromboembolism.

questions.text:
Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF is used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?

ARMD - age-related macular degeneration
questions.solution:
Intravitreal injection of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is used as the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).

Wet ARMD is characterized by retinal pigment epithelial detachment and choroidal/subretinal neovascularization.

Treatment of ARMD depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane:

  • For extrafoveal membrane - Laser photocoagulation
  • For subfoveal and juxta foveal membranes, treatment options are as follows:
    • Intravitreal injection of anti -VEGF agents
    • Photodynamic therapy - the dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from a diode
    • Transpupillary thermotherapy

RGX-314 is an anti-VEGF treatment delivered by gene therapy. It has the potential to block VEGF for years following a surgical procedure in which a harmless virus, called adeno-associated virus (AAV), carrying the anti-VEGF gene, is injected under the retina. This method is still under the trial.

questions.text: Abrasions are noted on the body of a person who was found dead at his home. Which of the following indicates that these might be produced after death?
questions.solution:
Abrasions present over bony prominences indicate that they might be produced after death. Antemortem abrasions may be located anywhere.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to casualty after falling from a balcony. Based on the CT scan finding provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity, consistent with an epidural hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the inner surface of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater, typically following a history of trauma. The characteristic biconvex shape arises due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of periosteal dura to the cranial sutures. If bleeding is significant, it may lead to a mass effect with herniation. 

Additionally, a swirl sign may be present, representing acute blood extravasation into a hematoma (extradural/subdural), showing fresh, unclotted blood with lower attenuation than the clotted blood (which is of a higher attenuation), highlighting the need for surgical intervention.

The following CT image depicts a swirl sign:

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding focal nodular hyperplasia?

choices.text: Resection is done for persistent symptomatic cases
Appears as hotspots in Tc 99m sulphur colloid scan

questions.solution:
Malignant transformation is unlikely in focal nodular hyperplasia.

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for FNH. It is seen as a well-circumscribed lesion with a typical central scar. They show intense homogeneous enhancement on the arterial phase and isodense as compared to the background liver on the venous phase.

Due to the presence of Kupffer cells, FNH appears as hotspots on Tc 99m sulphur colloid scans.

Asymptomatic patients with typical radiologic features do not require treatment. Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases.

Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection.

If diagnostic uncertainty exists, resection may be necessary for histologic confirmation.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids is a constituent of the human lung surfactant?
questions.solution:
Dipalmitoyl lecithin/Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is a major component of lung surfactant.

In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. 

Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus.

Clinical correlate :

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates is due to insufficient surfactant production.
  • Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.

Related Pearl: Pulmonary Surfactant Composition

Constituents

Percentage

Phospholipids, mainly dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)

70% to 80%

Proteins

10%

Neutral lipids

10%

questions.text: Which is the most common predisposing condition for infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Mitral regurgitation associated with mitral valve prolapse(MVP) is the most common predisposing condition for IE and is far more common than rheumatic mitral valve disease. 

The second most common native valve lesion predisposing to IE is aortic regurgitation.

Functional MR is quite uncommonly complicated by IE.

questions.text: An entomologist was studying a vector and the pathogen it transmits. He found that the pathogen underwent changes in number and morphology in the vector. What is this type of biological transmission called?
questions.solution:
This type of biological transmission where a pathogen undergoes a change in number and morphology in a vector is called cyclo-propagative transmission.

Malaria is a disease whose causative organism (Plasmodium sp.) undergoes cyclo-propagative transmission. In malaria, the parasite undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in the Anopheles mosquito (vector).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following nutritional deficiency is not associated with cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Zinc deficiency is not involved in pathogenesis of Cardiomyopathy.
Deficiencies of calcium, phosphate, and thiamine can produce cardiomyopathy

Nutritional deficiencies producing cardiomyopathy are:

  • Thiamine
  • Carnitine
  • Selenium
  • Calcium
  • Phosphate
  • Magnesium
